text: Only a few lights are burning at this hour. A limo pulls into the driveway, is met by SEVERAL DARK FIGURES. A MAN gets out, goes inside. Numbers fill the screen and form a super: “1987”
The man is MICHAEL DEAVER (late 40’s,) once an aide to President Reagan, now a lobbyist. He looks nervous. Grim.

Deaver hurries down a dark, nearly deserted hallway. The lights glimmer, casting ghostly shadows. He turns a corner, and heads down another hallway, where ARMED SECURITY GUARD who’s been waiting for him salutes. Deaver hurries on. The guard looks after him, his face filling with dislike. TWO MAIDS stand beside a linen closet, talking. They fall silent as Deaver passes, and stare suspiciously after him

Another SECURITY GUARD sitting in front of the Reagan bedroom door, watching a tiny tv, with the sound low: Oliver North talking with microphones shoved in his face. As Deaver approaches, the guard stands up, salutes.
Good evening, sir. They’re waiting for you. The guard knocks on the bedroom door with a gloved-hand.
Mr. Deaver to see the President. MUFFLED VOICES WITHIN. THEN, A WOMAN’S VOICE (NANCY) :
Let him in. The Guard opens the door for Deaver.

The room is dark, lit only by a flickering tv. Two ghosts are sitting in front of it: RONALD REAGAN (75) in bathrob and slippers, watching tv—-his eyes hollow, and dark. On table beside him, a glass of milk and a plate of Oreos. Next to him is his wife, NANCY (63). She’s pale, gaunt. S looks up at Deaver with eyes full of silent panic.
I got a call from John Tower..He wants to talk to you, Mr. President... Reagan is still staring into the tv. It’s a cowboy movie.
It’s okay, Mike. Go on. Deaver turns to Nancy, lowers his voice.
(in a whisper) They're beginning to talk about impeachment . She begins to tremble.
They’11 never impeach him. They won’t have the votes for it in the Senate.

I know but John thinks..so does George, and so do I..the evidence is overwhelming..and if the President doesn’t say something, Congress is going to start its own investigation..—d Meese and I and some of the other Republican Senators..well, we all think the President should hire a criminal practice attorney.
He‘s not a criminal. She begins to weep, silently. Deaver kneels beside Reagan and gently touches his arm. Reagan looks at him, confused 2
Why do I need an attorney?
(carefully, gently) No, you don’t need an attorney, Mr. : President, but you want to have one, that’s all. Have one to talk to. Someone to stand up for you.
Ronnie, we’ve got to have somebody.
We haven’t broken the law.
Nobody’s saying you’ve broken the law. It’s just there are so many questions...
Tell them to ask that bastard..that lying son of a gun, Oliver North! He’s the one who knows! Ask Oliver North who gave the money to the Contras—
They will, Mr. President..They will...
Ronnie, listen.Listen to me..We’ve got to do something..We’ve got to stand up for ourselves, for Christ’s sake. We can’t just keep sitting here, doing nothing.
But I’m not the one who broke the law.
Yes, Mr. President. I know.
You've got to talk to them.
I could set up a press conference— Nancy turns to Deaver, her panic flares: as”
No. No press conferences.
How's he going to talk?
He‘ll talk to the people. The people. They always believe him.
“Alright. But not before he’s gotten an attorney—
They got Nixon, and now they think they’re going to get me. Well, I’m not Nixon. I’m not. Nancy grabs his hand. Her grip is like iron.
Everybody knows that, Ronnie. All you have to do is talk to them. Talk to the people and make them believe you. Reagan wipes the tears off her cheek, kisses her tenderly

Okay, okay, Nancy-pants. Settle down. Don’t worry. I can handle this. Stop erying. (to Deaver, smiling) She cries more than any woman I know. She cries every time we send out the laundry. Deaver smiles. Nancy and Deaver get up, and go to the doo
As Nancy and Deaver come out, the Guard switches off Oliv North on the tv.
down the hall together. She leans on his arm, murmuring:
“Dire events,” she said. Well, these are dire events.
Who said that? Your friend?
She said the first few months of 1987. And it’s all happening the way she said it would. Everything. Deaver is careful to keep his voice even. DEAVER . Just make sure he gets an attorney.”
I will. And then I’11 call my friend..Find a good date for him to go on tv..We’ve got to listen to her, Mike. When we don’t listen to her, we get into trouble...

Okay, fine. Give me a date, and I'll set it up for the networks. She looks at him, smiles shakily. NANCY . Thank you, Mike. You’re the only one we ‘ can trust, you know. It’s come down to ~ you. Out of all these people..We’re surrounded by traitors.
Don’t worry. It’s going to be ok. It is. Nancy squeezes his arm gratefully. He leaves. ANGLE - As Nancy returns to her bedroom door, the securit guard has changed the channel to the cowboy movie.
I’m sorry, Mrs. Reagan. It was the guard before me who turned it on...
You're fired. She goes into the bedroom. The guard stares after her, stunned.
Reagan is staring into his movie, once again. Nancy puts her arms around him from behind, kisses his ear.
All I wanted to do was save those people. That’s all I wanted.
I know..I know..I love you..I love you. MOVE IN ON his eyes, dark and confused...

The lithe body of an expert swimmer rising to the surface of a perfect blue body of water. In slow motion, the body breaks through the water. Golden sun reflects off the wet skin and hair of this beautiful young man (a young Reagan dressed only in a 1920’s lifeguard uniform. The image of god. The perfect American hero. MUSIC FADES UP: Doris Day singing “SENTIMENTAL JOURNEY”:
(singing) Gonna take a sentimental journey Gonna see my heart's desire...
INT./EXT. REAGAN’S 1948 CADILLAC CONVERTIBLE/MOVING -

Numbers fill the screen, as they will throughout: “1949” Reagan (38) drives through a gorgeous Hollywood afternoon singing along to DORIS DAY ON THE RADIO. He’s wearing glasses, and a cast on his left leg. Two crutches are on the seat beside him.
(singing) Gonna take a sentimental journey Gonna take that journey home...
Reagan’s green convertible driving onto the lot. He smile and waves, as he passes ACTORS, CREW MEMBERS, etc.

Reagan parks and gets out, using his crutches. He limps past a COUPLE OF STARLET BELLYDANCERS. They smile at him. He smiles back. He passes TWO ACTORS IN BLACK-FACE, working on a tap-danc routine... He passes A GROUP OF ACTORS IN TUXES AND GOWNS clustered around a lunch wagon, eating as if they haven't eaten in days. He opens a stage door marked “East Side, West Side”, and enters.
The set is a NYC apartment. A FILM CREW is crawling all over it, setting up for the next take. Reagan approaches the director, MERVYN LEROY (50’s), who’s talking to his D
Hi, Mervyn. LeRoy turns, smiles, sees Reagan’s leg.
Good God, Ronnie..what have you done to yourself?
Don’t ask. A charity baseball game. I tried to win one for the Gipper.
(laughs) Thanks for coming down. I hope I’m not taking you away from anything.
It's fine. I’m not working. I mean, I have the day off. The DP leaves. LeRoy takes Reagan by the elbow, walks him towards an isolated corner. They drop their voices:

Alright, listen. This is the thing. I’ve got this actress. Over there, see her? Leroy nods to a young woman nearby, sitting by herself. It’s Nancy, elegant, strong-jawed. She’s in costume-a pla ‘etl  secretary's dress—smoking a cigarette. She’s deep into a movie-magazine.

Her name's Nancy Davis. Just came out from Chicago. Extremely conservative. Extremely Republican, if you know what I mean. Anyway, last week, the Hollywood Reporter came out with a list of Communist sympathizers, and her name was on it.
(carefully) Oh, yeah?

Of course she’s upset. Scared about her career, her apartment, her friends. She asked me for advice. I said I knew you, and since you were President of the Screen Actors Guild, maybe you could help. Reagan hesitates, looking at Nancy suspiciously.
So she’s not a Communist sympathizer?

No way. I’m telling you, she’s Republican. Father’s a society doctor in Chicago. That‘s why she’s upset, she keeps saying, if he finds out, she’s screwed. (pause) Anyway, that’s it. Think you can look into it?
Sure. Let me see what I can find out. LeRoy glances at Nancy, then back to Reagan. Lowers his voice still further:
Do me one more favor—take her out to dinner, or something. You know, just to set her mind at ease.
(groan) Dinner?
Nothing expensive. Just something nice. I’m telling you, she’s a wreck. Reagan glances at Nancy again. She doesn’t look like a wreck.
(reluctantly) Yeah, well. Okay. I‘11 do it.
Thanks, Ronnie. You’re a pal. LeRoy starts back toward the set. Reagan pulls him back.
Hey, Mervyn..Since I’m doing you a favor?
Anything.
Cast me in whatever you’re doing next.
(laughs) You got it. LeRoy starts toward the set. Reagan calls after him:
As long as it’s good. No B-movie stuff.
Gotcha. ANGLE - Nancy looking up from her movie-magazine, watchin him leave.
It’s an article on Reagan-pictures of the break-up betwee him and his wife, Jane Wyman. The headline reads: ‘Heart- broken Ronnie: “I’1ll Never Love Again.”

head_text.subj: A SHADOW FALLS ACROSS THE MAGAZINE

text: Nancy looks up, as LeRoy whispers into her ear: Nees?
Mission accomplished. Nancy laughs, delighted. She has a gorgeous smile.
Mervyn, you're a peach!

Reagan’s green Cadillac pulls up outside Nancy’s modest building. INT. LIVING ROOM - NANCY’S APARTMENT - CONTINUING Nancy watches through the blinds, as he limps up the walk Checks herself in a mirror—she’s deeply insecure about he looks. The doorbell RINGS. She takes a deep breath.
Reagan smiles, as she comes out.
It’s so nice of you to make time for me, you must be terribly busy...
It’s okay. I’m afraid we’ll only have time for a quick bite. I’ve got an early call tomorrow.
Me, too. As they walk to the car..
Mervyn told me about your leg. It looks awfully painful.

It’s not so bad, anymore. As long as you don't make me dance. They both laugh. INT. EXPENSIVE RESTAURANT (LARUE’S) - EVENING The WAITER hands them menus, and leaves. Nancy lights a cigarette and listens intently, as Reagan quietly explain 10

Okay, here’s the deal. There are a bunch of petitions going around-trying to solicit the Supreme Court against the House Un-American Activities Committee. Your name appeared on one of those petitions, which is how it ended up in the Hollywood Reporter.
But I didn’t sign any petitions. I didn’t. I’m the least political person I know.
It’s okay. I made a few phone calls, and the Nancy Davis who. signed this particular petition lives over on Cahuenga Boulevard. A completely different Nancy Davis.
(sighing with relief. I knew it.
In fact, if you want to know, Nancy Davis is a pretty popular name. There are 3 of you in Los Angeles.
(horrified) Three?
Yeah. If I were you, I’d think about changing my name.
(snorts) Forget it. Nancy Davis is my name. Let the other girls change theirs. He laughs, impressed.

I like your attitude. Now, let’s see if we can find anything edible on this menu. INT. LARUE’S - NIGHT The lights have dimmed. The room is thick with cigarette candles on every table. In the shadows, BEAUTIFUL 11 Nie?
WOMEN laugh and murmur over martinis with their WEALTHY ESCORTS. Reagan and Nancy have long since finished dinner.
My mother used to be an actress. My father - is a brain surgeon, I got my hands from him. Anyway, he’s the one with political beliefs. He hates the Reds. Hates them. Reagan sighs.

I was an FDR Democrat until the war. I still believe in the Democratic party. But the Democrats..they don’t get it. They won't believe that Moscow’s trying to take over the world. They’ve taken over half of Europe. Czechoslovakia. China. And now they’re here in America, trying to take over Hollywood. I'11 tell you-anybody in their right mind ought to be scared stiff. Nancy nods, in agreement. He smiles.
Sorry. When we came out tonight, all I wanted to do was show you a good time.
It's okay. You talk the way my father talks. Only nicer..Never mind. She smiles, embarrassed. He smiles, too.
Too bad you’ve got an early call.
You, too. Pause. Now it’s his turn to look embarrassed.
You know, Nancy..I’ve got a little confession to make...
Yeah, I know. I don’t have one, either. They laugh. 12

Say, Sophie Tucker’s singing at Ciro’s. You want to go? EXT. CIRO’S - NIGHT Ciro's is swinging. SOPHIE TUCKER’S VOICE IS ROCKING THE STREET, as Reagan. on crutches, escorts Nancy inside. INT. CIRO’S - LATER The place is packed, as SOPHIE TUCKER sings. Everyone. is drunk, dancing. Reagan and Nancy are dancing--slowly. He' leaning on one crutch, and her.

I was finally getting some good parts when the war came along. Then I was drafted. When I got back, it was all..different. All these young actors. Suddenly I felt like I was..out of fashion. Nancy nods, sympathetically.
Did you see much action during the war?
Look into my eyes. What do you see? She does. He has nice eyes. Honest.
(wryly) Contact lenses. Blind as a bat without them, kept me out of combat. I spent the war in Culver City making films for the Army. The Hollywood Commandos. She laughs.
I talk too much, don’t I? That’s what Jane said, when she filed for divorce. I talk too damn much.
It's okay. I’m a Cancer. I like listening. 13

He looks at her. Slowly, he leans toward her..They kiss. arms tighten around him. When the kiss ends, they keep dancing. Looking into each other’s eyes. INT. DEPARTMENT STORE (MAGNIN’S, BEVERLY HILLS) - DAY In a VIP dressing room, Nancy tries on a new dress, looks at herself critically, in the mirror. It’s fashionable, expensive..but somehow all wrong.
If you ask me, that Ronald Reagan is the best-looking man you’ve had in a while. If you don’t grab him, somebody else will.
What am I supposed to do? Throw a rope around him? EDITH LUCKETT DAVIS (50'S), Nancy’s mother, is an earthy woman, former actress, stylish in furs and jewels.

No, but it wouldn’t hurt if you dressed better. God, you look awful. It’s your skin. I never saw anybody with such sallow skin. (calling) Hey! Somebody! Who the hell is out there? The SALESWOMAN peeks in the door, gritting her teeth.
Yes, Mrs. Davis?
Aren’t you supposed to be helping us? Get my daughter something that’1l make her look decent, for Chrissakes. The Saleswoman is seething, as she leaves.
Mother, I wish you’d keep your voice down.

Why? You should be glad I’ve got a big voice-that’s how I made my career. And yours, too, little girl. If I wasn’t friends with Spencer Tracy, do you think 14  you'd be out here in Hollywood, with your very own contract? As Edith pulls a silver cigarette case out of her purse, and lights it, Nancy sighs:
I just don’t think Ronnie wants to get serious about me. Anybody. I mean, God, his wife threw him out. Can you imagine how humiliating that would be? Listening is not Edith’s strong suit.
I know what--tell him you want to meet his kids. Show him what a great mother you’11 make, that‘1ll get him. Nancy suddenly remembers, looks at her watch:
We're late for Dr. Loyal.
Christ. Strip off that rag-we’ve got to run.
A string quartet plays MOZART in the corner. Nancy sits next to her step-father, DR. LOYAL DAVIS (50’s). He’s holding her hand and stroking it, as Edith looks on, beaming.
Nancy, I don’t know what you see in Hollywood. As far as I can tell, it’s nothing but Communists and drug addicts.
It didn’t used to be this bad—did it, Mother?
Hell, no. When I was here, it was just wall-to-wall Jews and queers. Loyal laughs-Nancy stiffens. 15
(wiping his mouth with a napkin) Well, frankly, I think we should consider heading to Phoenix early. Nancy, darling— you come, too.
I wish I could, but Dr. Loyal, you know I’m working.
We're going to see the Goldwaters. You love spending time with the Goldwaters.
I really can’t. I’m sorry...
Ask her about Ronnie Reagan.
Nancy, no! You’re not serious about him, are you?

No, not at all. Well, yes, but..0h please, Dr. Loyal. He’s the only man I’ve ever met who could hold a candle to you. EXT. NANCY’S BATHROOM DOOR - DAY The bathroom door is ajar, as NANCY’S VOICE IS HEARD:
“Jews and queers.” You bigot, Mother. Why didn’t I tell you to shut up? But I never would, would I? Why not?

head_text.subj: AROUND THE CORNER OF THE DOOR

text: Nancy is taking a bubble- bath, ranting to herself:
Because I’m a coward, that’s what. Coward. Coward, coward, coward, coward, coward— DOORBELL RINGS. Nancy glances at the clock on the wall.
Oh Christ! He’s early! EXT. NANCY’S DOOR - CONTINUING 16  Reagan turns, calls to TWO CHILDREN waiting in the car.
Michael, stop hitting your sister! Mermie, stay in the car! Do not-do you hear me—do not get out of the car! The door opens. Nancy's wet face, wet hair.
Ronnie..Hi...
You ready? I brought the kids, I thought we could go out to the ranch and go horseback-riding. What do you think? Nancy looks at the kids, looks at him. Puts on a smile.

Give me 2 secs. EXT. RONNIE’S RANCH (MALIBU CANYON) - DAY Nancy’s awkward on her horse, as they start out. He grabs her reins, leads her toward the gate. The two kids are following, on their horses-MAUREEN (10) and MICHAEL (5).
Come on, Nancy. Pull in those reins, let him know who’s boss.
(barely hanging on) I think he already knows.
(laughs) Mermie! Mike! Let’s take Nancy down to the pond! He spurs his horse ahead, leaving her with the kids. They pass thru a gate with an ornate metal sign: YEARLING ROW.
You kids are pretty good at this. Whoa. Whoa, Sugar. 17 Neanav?
We've been riding since we were 2. Have you ever won an Oscar?
(taken aback) An Oscar?
Mommy has. She won an Oscar for “Johnny Belinda”. Mike interrupts:
I’m special because I’m adopted. Nancy turns to Mike, even more taken aback. NANCY. You're what?
He’s adopted. Daddy wanted a boy so they adopted one. (to Mike) You’re not special. You're a brat.
You’re a brat!
Daddy! Mikey called me a brat! The argument continues. Nancy smiles weakly. They ride on
A picnic under a tree. The kids play in the distance, as Reagan and Nancy lounge in the shade. He’s reminiscing:
Those were the best days of my life— sitting up high in that lifeguard chair. Watching out for all those families. In 7 years, I saved 77 lives.
Seventy-seven? 18
With a little help from God. But it was pretty good for a scrawny kid from Dixon, Iowa, who grew up over a bank. Actually, that was as close as I ever got to that bank. They both laugh. Pause.
You never talk about your folks. What were they like? Reagan doesn’t seem to hear her. He gets up and calls:
Mermie! Mike! Time to head back! The kids run for their horses. He goes to his horse. Nanc watches him, curiously--then gets up, and heads to hers.
A chain-smoking COSTUME LADY (50s) is flipping through Modern Screen as Nancy looks dejectedly at a rack of housedresses.
Maybe I could wear something different for this part. Something a little more—
You/re playing a housewife, doll. Your wardrobe has to say housewife. Sighing, Nancy chooses a dress; looks at some aprons.

Hey, .look at this. You're in Modern Screen. Shows her a small photo of Reagan and “starlet Nancy Davi at a premiere—under a large one of him and Jane Wyman: “Ronnie Dates Again But Can’t Forget His Perfect Love.” Nancy stares at it, stung..
Slip this on under the dress. She’s holding a bulbous rubber object— 19
It’s your pregnancy pad. You get pregnant in act two.
Reagan walks with his agent, LEW WASSERMAN (30’s).
This is a mistake, Lew. I can’t afford another bad picture.
Come on--it’s a fun movie and I bet it’1l make a lot of money.
We should have waited for a better offer—

The offers aren’t coming, Ronnie. The studios are drying up. But all that Red Menace crap doesn’t help, either. You know a lot of people around town are convinced you're an informer for the blacklist.
Yeah, yeah, yeah. I keep telling you, Lew, there is no blacklist.
And thank God we’re not on it. (pause) All I'm saying is, lay off the Evil Empire talk. I can get you all the work you want in television—
Forget it. Television is for somebody who’s all washed up. I’m not washed up. At the stage door, a PUBLICIST and PHOTOGRAPHER wait.

Hey, Ronnie! How ya doin’? Ready to meet your co-star? The photographer gets ready. The publicist opens the stag door, and out bursts a CHIMP and his TRAINER. The chimp i wearing a t-shirt that says “Bedtime for Bonzo”. 20
(laughing) Hey, Bonzo! Shake hands with Mr. Reagan! Big smiles, you two! Bonzo starts jumping all over Reagan. Reagan tries to tur on a smile as a FLASHBULB POPS.
Reagan and Nancy are watching “Casablanca” on tv, as Reag and Nancy finish a bowl of popcorn. She’s subdued. Smokin
(re: Bogart) That was supposed to be my part, you know. They wanted me to play it, but I was busy. Busy doing nothing..Bogart gets Ingrid Bergman, I get a chimp.
You’re still in love with her, aren’t you? The words have popped out of her mouth before she could stop them. Reagan looks at her, stunned.
Who?
Jane. You're still in love with her. You even told Modern Screen. “Heartbroken Ronnie Tries to Forget his Great Love”.
Nancy, come off it. Those magazines are a bunch of crap, you know that. (joking) Thank God they still think I’m worth writing about. He turns back to the movie. She stares at him in disbelie
Ronnie, look at me. Ronnie. He looks at her. She summons up her nerve.
I want to know where I stand with you. 21 Neves
You know where we stand.

I don’t know anything. We go out, we laugh, we... (embarrassed, dropping her voice) We make love..but I don’t know anything about you, about how you feel. Oh you talk plenty about everything else-politics, the industry. But not about me. Not to me. His eyes harden. He looks trapped.
I don’t talk about those things, Nancy. You know that.
Why not? You’re an actor, you play people who have feelings. Come on. Tell me about your feelings. No response. She gets up.
It’s late. We both have early calls. Nancy takes the bowl into the kitchen. He stares moodily the popcorn in his hand.
I’ve told my agent to find me something in New York. On the stage. I’ve had it with Hollywood. He gets up, follows her into the kitchen, where she’s washing the popcorn bowl.
You can’t go back to New York...
Is there some reason I should stay here? (off his silence.) No, I didn’t think so. He grabs her arm, swings her around. He’s angry.
You can’t do this to me. 22  He starts kissing her, hard. Desperate. She pulls back, surprised. He pushes her against the sink, still kissing her. The tap water run and runs.
Wealthy. Intellectual. Midwestern. Nancy sits in a chair, erying. Edie sits, opposite. They whisper:
Well, one thing is clear—you can‘t tell Ronnie. He’s too religious, he’ll never marry you.
I can’t tell him?
But you’d better get him to marry you. And quick. You don’t have any time to lose.
I can’t force him marry me, Mother. For God’s sake. She sobs hysterically.
Shh, keep it down, or Dr. Loyal will hear you— Nancy can't stop crying. Edith pats her on the arm.

(in a whisper, anxiously) Don’t worry, honey. Don’t worry, we’ll get it fixed. I know somebody right here in Chicago, she can fix it. She’s good. She never hurts anybody. But we can never tell Dr. Loyal, you hear? Never. Never. Nancy stares at her mother, stricken. INT. SOUND STAGE - “THE NEXT. VOICE YOU HEAR” — DAY The set is a drab tenement kitchen. Nancy stands in the shadows, smoking a cigarette. She’s in costume: a house- dress with a pregnancy-pad. She looks utterly miserable. The COSTUME-LADY pushes and pulls the pregnancy-pad: 23 aaa
These pregnancy pads are a joke. Hold still. Hold still. (looking at her) You look sick. You sick?
- I’m fine.
(from the shadows) Okay, we’ve reset. Nancy, you ready? Nancy stubs out her cigarette, and goes to the table, sit down. Reagan appears in the shadows, watching her.
Do we have rain? What’s the matter with the rain? Hold please. Hold. Nancy settles down for a long wait.
Nancy?
(turns, sees) Ronnie? What are you doing here? Nancy gets up, crosses to him in the. shadows.
What’s the matter?
Nancy, where are you? Where the hell did you go?
(to the director) I’m talking to somebody, okay?
Don’t leave. We'll be ready in a minute. Reagan pulls Nancy further into the shadows, desperate.

Okay, here it is. My father was a drunk. Everywhere we lived, he’d lose his job, because of the drink..I remember when I was young, coming home from the YMCA one 24  afternoon..and there he was on our lawn, passed out drunk in the snow. It broke my heart to see him like that..He must have been in so much pain. I had to drag him inside. (pause) But my mother..she kept right on living the way she thought was right. She was always good to my father. She never held it against him, no matter how many jobs he lost, or how often we moved..She was the one who kept the family together.
I understand, Ronnie. I do.
No, you don’t. You come from Chicago—
I had it tough, too—
But your father had money. Money is everything.

Dr. Loyal isn’t my father. My real father left, before I was born. My mother was broke, she went on the road just to make money, and stuck me with her sister for 6 years. For 6 years, I cried myself to sleep, every night. So don’t tell me I’ve never had trouble, because I have. Reagan is stunned, looking at her.
I love you. I’d do anything for you. Ask me to crawl halfway across the country for you, I would. On my knees. On my knees. She’s on the verge of tears, touches him, whispering:
Ronnie, don’t say that. Please..You don’t know..I’m pregnant. He looks down at her pregnancy-pad. 25
Yeah, and you look cute as a bug, too. He puts his arms around her, picks her up. Kisses her.
Come here, Mommy. You want to marry me?
| Ronnie, stop it..you don’t mean it...
I do. I love you, Nancy..I really do, I love you...
26  INT. LEW WASSERMAN’S OFFICE - DAY
Newco?” SUPER: “1953” Lew’s uncomfortable, awkward, as he pushes an envelope across the table to Reagan, and tries to explain: Reagan takes
It's not you, Ronnie. It’s Warner Brothers. Now that the Government forced the studios to sell off their theatres, they can’t afford their stable of stars.
It’s because my movies haven't been making enough money. That’s why they’re letting me go.
(re: the envelope) Go on, take it. It’s your last paycheck. the envelope, stunned.
I worked for those bastards for 13 years— Ne”

They’d fire their own mother, if it would help them balance their books right now. (cautiously) Listen to me. I know you said you’d never do television, but I think I’ve engineered a deal with GE. They’re going to doa series and they want you to host it. A different story every week, some of them starring you. And there'd be speaking engagements, too, you’d be their spokesman—
(dubiously) A spokesman..for General Electric?
You’d go around the country, talking to employees and consumers. When people see GE, they’d think of you. Nao” Reagan is getting more depressed by the minute. 27
Oh great.
It’s going to be a lot of money. A lot.
Yeah, and the government will take out 94% of it in taxes. I’m telling you, Lew, I don’t know why I bother working. Reagan gets up, heads for the door.

Think about it. It’s a good opportunity. Keep you in the public eye. Then, when that next picture comes along..bang. Talk to Nancy, and call me. They want an answer as soon as possible... Reagan’s gone. The door hangs open, allowing a view of the SECRETARY, AND A COUCHFUL OF ACTORS.
A small hour, immaculate garden. The EAR-SPLITTING SCREAM of an enraged toddler.
“Dr. Spock’s Child Care” on the floor, covered with cerea Nancy is on the phone, with a finger in one ear, as PATTI (2) screams, and sends her bowl of cereal flying.
(into the phone) We’d love to come to Phoenix, Mother, but we're a little busy right now.
Swathed in caftan and turban, Edie takes a martini from Loyal and sips, rolling her eyes heavenward with delight.
The Goldwaters keep asking me about you, I told them you’re married to Ronald Reagan, they can’t believe it. They’re dying to 28  meet him. You can fly down on Friday, spend the weekend—
(covering the mouthpiece, hissing) Patti! Stop it! Stop it! Stop it!
What? I can’t hear you—
Oh God, Mother, I’d love to come down. But...Patti!
--we're having a party Friday night. Dr. Loyal will make you a martini that’s out of this world—
I‘ll talk to Ronnie.
Promise.
I will. Bye, Mother. Nancy hangs up the phone, turns to her purpling child, an SCREAMS BACK at her.
The hotel is surrounded by lush bougainvillea and palm trees--the watering-place for local and imported wealthy.
In shorts, golf shirts and deep tans, Loyal Davis, Ronnie and Arizona Senator BARRY GOLDWATER sip tall drinks and discuss politics. Reagan dandles Patti on his lap, while:

In this country we don’t make a man join a church and tithe..We don’t insist he join a fraternal order and pay dues..but union bosses like Hoffa can force that man to join the union and pay his dues, or he doesn’t work. Loyal leans over to Reagan, proudly: 29 Newie”
That’s what I like about Barry. He shoots straight from the hip.

But the federal government is worse than the unions. The Republicans are taking control of business. They killed the movie studios. And liberal Democrats are leading us down the road to socialism..The welfare state has done as much to destroy our way of life as the Commies. Right, Shorty?
Right. In the b.g., Edie crosses with 2 martinis to Nancy, who lies on a chaise, exhausted, sunning herself.
Those two are going to have your husband voting Republican before the day is over.
Let them try. The Reagans. have been Democrats for generations.
Well, we’ll see what happens, once he starts working at GE. I hope you take his first pay-check to hire yourself a nanny and a housekeeper. I didn’t raise you to wait table on a toddler.
| (wincing) Oh God. I want to be a good mother. I do. Edie scoffs, pats Nancy on the arm consolingly:
You're no worse than I was. The only thing that’s important is you and Ronnie. Kids will come and go, but if you’re good to Ronnie, you'll have him for the duration.

The three Reagans smiling from the cover of TV GUIDE. REAGANS’ HOUSE - PACIFIC PALISADES - DAY A FILM CREW is swarming all over the living room, setting up lights, cameras, etc. Reagan sits in the middle, putti on his own make-up, as he tells a joke:

Did you hear the one about the two little kids, one’s an optimist, and the other’s a pessimist? Their parents gave the pessimist a shiny new bike to teach him that things weren’t always so bad. And to teach the optimist that things weren’t always so good, they gave him a big pile of horse manure— (pause) Well, when the pessimist saw the bike, he burst into tears, sure he’d fall off and hurt himself. But the little optimist just smiled. He knew that somewhere around all that manure, there had to be a pony. The crew laughs. INT. UPSTAIRS - PATTI’S BEDROOM - CONTINUING Nancy arguing with Patti, (5), who won’t come down.
Come on, Patti. They’re all set to go.
No. I won’t. I want to stay up here and play. Nancy grits her teeth, and takes Patti by the wrist.
No arguing. We're going down, right now.
No! No! No! No! NO! NO! Nancy reaches out, and slaps Patti. Patti reels, holding her cheek. Nancy freezes. 31 Seca
I’m sorry. I’m sorry, Patti..I’m sorry... Patti begins to cry. Nancy picks her up, and carries her out of the room.

Chandelier over the table, which is set with enough linen silver and flowers to satisfy Emily Post. Beautifully dressed and coiffed, Nancy, Reagan, and Patti eat lunch a if this is the way they always live.
Daddy, what’s ‘lectricity?
Well, Patti, electricity is a wonderful thing. Let’s go into the kitchen and maybe I can explain it.

text: Which is state of the art, GE’s logo prominent everywhere
We ought to be able to find lots of electrical appliances in here. (picks up an iron from counter) What’s this?
Mommy's iron.
That’s right, it’s one of the new steam- and-dry irons.
(overriding) I’m hungry. Can we cut now? ANGLE - the Film Crew howling with laughter.
Cut! Okay, everybody! Take ten!
(to Patti, exasperated) That’s the third time you stepped on my line. What am I going to do with you? 32
She puts her hands around Patti’s neck, and laughing, pretends to strangle her. As everyone laughs:

It's raining against the windows. SOUND: THUNDER. A sign at the door says: “Meet Ronald Reagan in Person: GE'S Roving Ambassador of Good Will”. The room’s packed with GE EMPLOYEES, all male, white, in white short-sleeve shirts and black ties, listening, as:

America is a land of unlimited opportunity—all of us here are proof of that. We’re blessed with the freedom to make of ourselves whatever we want to be. In the back of the room, a man (BEN WELDEN, 40) is quietl watching the response.

But there are people who want to take that freedom away from us—big government that rewards laziness with welfare-that wants to tell you how to pray, and what doctor you'll see, and what school you’ll send your kids to! Some employees applaud in agreement.

Gentlemen, you and I have a rendezvous with destiny. Will we preserve our American way of life? Or doom our children to a lifetime of tyranny?? An explosion of applause. Welden watches, impressed. INT. GE LUNCHROOM ~— LATER Welden hovers as Ronnie signs autographs, surrounded by enthusiastic employees.
Just a couple more, fellas. I got to go to Atlanta.
Need a lift to the train station? INT./EXT. WELDEN’S CAR - MOVING - STREET ~ DAY 33 ‘sai? The rain pelts against the windshield. Ronnie’s exhauste trying to rest. Welden talks:
Quite a flag-waver you gave. Company give you a script? i REAGAN | The words are mine. So are the convictions.
And that thing about “Rendezvous with Destiny”. That’s good.
It's FDR.
You a Democrat? (Ronnie nods tiredly) You sure don’t talk like one.
The Democrats have changed, not me.
My name’s Welden. Ben Welden. I work for the Republican Party. I’ve got a few friends you might like to meet.
(suspiciously) Why?

Why not? They’re people, just like you and me. People who care about their country. Besides, my friends are going to be real, real interested in you. INT. REAGANS’ PALISADES BEDROOM - LATE DAY Wearing a silk slip,. hair pin-curled, Nancy scowls at th half-dozen evening dresses spread out on the bed.
Ronnie? Honey, come and choose for me, will you? No response. She crosses to the intercom by the door. 34
A button for every room in the house. Nancy’s finger presses Nursery. HEAR, CLEARLY:
Well, saying your prayers is like talking to God..God listens. to you, like I do.
Mommy doesn’t.
What do you mean?
Mommy doesn’t listen to me. She hits me.
She doesn’t hit you.
She does, too. She hit me tonight, when I wouldn’t take a bath.
Listen, Shorty, maybe she spanks you, but when I was your age, I got spanked a lot, too, That’s what parents do.
(sullenly) You’re always on her side.

Go to sleep. Close your eyes. Nancy leans against the wall, reeling with guilt. EXT. ALFRED BLOOMINGDALE’S HOUSE, BEVERLY HILLS - NIGHT A crowd of WEALTHY REPUBLICAN COUPLES milling around unde a large white tent, dancing to a small band, drinking, flirting, gossiping, etc. Ronnie is sitting with a group of PROMINENT BUSINESSMEN. The men are all half-drunk, laughing, as he says:
Well, you know what I always say..Big Government‘s like a baby—a big appetite at 35
one end, and no responsibility at the other... The men ROAR with laughter. Ben Welden approaches, with ALFRED BLOOMINGDALE AND HOLMES TUTTLE.
Ronnie..I want you to meet two friends of mine. Alfred Bloomingdale, and Holmes Tuttle.
Hello, gentlemen. Alfred and Holmes take the cigars out of their mouths, lo enough to shake hands.
Ben here says you’re a Democrat. That true? Holmes intervenes, with a grin:
Yeah, he’s a Democrat. For now. Everybody laughs. Reagan looks a little nervous.
Nancy is sitting with a group of women..They’re all drink and smoking. Her smile is showing signs of strain.
I had all the kids’ horoscopes done just last year. You won’t believe what I found out.
Carol? Did she do them?
Only the best for those little monsters. Everyone laughs. Nancy leans over to the woman next to he who is bleached-blonde, tanned, face-lifted. Her name is BETSY BLOOMINGDALE.
Excuse me..is she talking about Carol Ryder,.the astrologer? 36

You’ve never met Carol? She’s a genius. She knows what days are good, and what days are bad. She’11 tell you when it’s okay to get on a plane, when to ask fora promotion, and even what boarding school to put your children in. WOMAN 3 leans over, whispers to both of them:
Carol told me about this girls’ school in northern California. We sent our two daughters there, they’ve never been happier. And it saved my marriage. Betsy laughs. As Woman 3 returns to her drink:
Betsy Bloomingdale.
Nancy Reagan. Nancy takes a sip of her drink, then cautiously ventures:
I wonder if she could tell me whether I’m having a boy, or a girl.
Honey, don’t tell me you’re pregnant.
Only just. Ronnie wants a boy. So do I.
So you won’t have to go through it again. I’ll drink to that. Betsy laughs, drinks. So does Nancy. She’s found a friend
Reagan brings in a cup of warm milk to Nancy, as she’s climbing into bed, exhausted.
I liked those people tonight. They were really nice people, don’t you think? And 37 Nei”
rich. I’ve never seen so many rich people in one place.
Ronnie, you’ve met plenty of rich people in Hollywood.

But not like this. This is different. Texaco. Shell. Mobile Oil. And these people don’t even look tired. They look like they spend all their time on vacation. (Nancy laughs) Yeah, nice fellows. Real nice fellows. A couple of them asked me if I’d ever thought of running for Senator. Nancy stops laughing.
Senator? You?
In the spring primary. Why not? I’d be sort of like Jimmy Stewart, you know? In “Mr. Deeds Goes to Washington"?
Ronnie, that’s a movie. There's alsoa little matter of them being Republicans, and you being a Democrat. Unless you’re thinking about switching parties. Are you? (off his silence) Ronnie?
Do you want me to switch?
(evasively) «Dr. Loyal would like it.

No. No, I don’t want to be a Republican. Hell, I want to act. Acting is the only thing I ever wanted to do. And if I can just keep with this GE thing long enough— I'll get back into the movies, I will. Sooner or later. 38
Well, every producer in Hollywood is a Democrat. If you want to be an actor, I guess you’ve got to stay a Democrat.
I know. I’m an actor, not a politician. - Say, where’s my script? Want to help me run lines for tomorrow? Reagan heads into the bathroom for his toothbrush.

Sure, but first I want to talk to you about something. One of the women at the party was talking about a boarding school for. girls, up north. She went on and on, about it. It’s supposed to be real nice.
You mean, for Patti? On the wall beside Nancy’s head, a little red light is blinking. It’s the intercom. INT. PATTI’S ROOM - Patti sits in bed in the dark, listening.
Not now, but when she gets a little older. Boarding school can be good for girls, particularly girls like Patti.
Maybe you’re right. Mermie and Michael went to boarding school. It’s up to you, Nancy-pants. You’re running the show.
39 Saw
Nancy in bed, looking up at Reagan as he holds BABY RON. the b.g., Edith and Loyal Davis, hugging Patti.
Hi, Skipper... (hugging him) I’ve got a son..a son..You're going to be a chip off the old block, aren’t you, kid?

“GE Theater, Episode #284; Scene 49, Take 1”. On action, Reagan (the Sheriff) begins duking it out with the Bad Gu Reagan throws a punch and the Bad Guy goes for his gun. Reagan’s faster: he draws, pulls the trigger, but—click, click-the gun doesn’t fire. Reagan deadpans to the Bad Gu
Mind if I borrow your gun? The Bad Guy cracks up, so does the rest of the set. A.D. Oh Christ. What’s the matter with the gun? Guys, why can’t we get this right?

Yeah, I’m giving a talk at the VFW tonight. If you don’t watch out, I'11 name you as a threat to American freedom. LAUGHTER. As they fix the problem, Lew Wassermen has been watching from the dark. Reagan crosses to him, and says:
So, Lew..What’s with the face? Lew takes him into a corner.
I got another call from GE--
My speeches make them nervous, I know.
They’re getting too extreme. 40
Come on, Lew. The Reds are making a bomb to blow us up, and I’m being “too extreme” ? Lew pulls Reagan further into the corner. Quietly:
The head of GE heard you give a speech at the plant in Tarrytown. He said you sounded like some kind of right-wing reactionary nut. Democrats buy GE products, too, so lay off the Commie- thing.
I’m not going out there to peddle toasters, Lew.
You're going to push General Electric to the wall?
They’re not going to fire me.
But they can sure as hell cancel the show.
And you’re going to support them against me? Silence. This is suddenly looking like a parting of the ways.

Ready! Ronnie, we’ve got your gun! Reagan turns on his heel, and goes back to work. Lew star after him, irritably. INT. PALISADES HOUSE - BABY’S ROOM - AFTERNOON Nancy bending over Ron’s crib, making sure he’s asleep. Suddenly, the TV BLARES from the next room. Nancy stiffen
Patti watching tv. Nancy enters, angrily snaps it off. 41
Hey!
Patti, I told you 3 times. Not. While. Baby. Ron. Is. Napping. Patti turns the tv back on.
Patti? Did you hear me? Patti ignores her. Nancy starts to slap her, but stops.

Go to your room! Now! NOW! Patti saunters off. Nancy snaps off the tv. STAY ON NANCY, seeing herself in the mirror—an angry mom. She winces at her reflection, pats her hair into place. She doesn’t see the MAID behind the door, watching...
Reagan pulls into the driveway, turns off the engine, sit in the car. Nancy appears in the screen’door, with Patti. She comes out, alone.
So did you do it? Reagan gets out of the car. She puts her arms around him.
Yeah. It’s over. They wanted me to stop talking, and I’m not going to.
Good. I’m proud of you. You’ll be happier making movies.
Maybe.
Did you talk to Lew? 42
I can’t even get him on the phone.
(stunned) What? nn
Yeah. Funny, isn’t it? Why am I surprised? He hates everything I stand for.
Oh God, Ronnie..He’s been your agent since the beginning. How can he do this to you--
I don’t know—
And now he’s betrayed you...

It’s over, okay? Don’t look at me like that. I'll get a new agent. And a new job. I have a family to support, don’t I? He twists away from her, and goes into the house, pushing past Patti in the doorway.

That poor woman... As John-John salutes his father’s coffin..Little Ron grin and salutes, too. Nancy grabs him, holding him tightly:
No, Ronnie, no. Don’t do that.
WATCHING THRU THE WINDOW - NANCY’S POV ~ 43
Reagan sitting beside the pool, talking to Ben Welden and blonde man (Mike Deaver) .
Hello..is this Miss Ryder?
Yes.
My name is Nancy Reagan. My husband..my husband is—
Ronald Reagan. The actor. Yes. ANGLE - NANCY IN HER BEDROOM On the phone. Terrified.

(into the phone) Well, the thing is, Miss Ryder..Some people are trying to get my husband to go into politics..the Republicans..They want him to switch parties, and make speeches for Barry Goldwater, but he keeps telling them, he’s an actor, and..I don’t know..Everything’s so mixed up..I just wonder if you could just tell me whether we’re on the right path..Hello? INTERCUT WITH CAROL RYDER’S MOUTH, TALKING INTO HER PHONE
Would you rather have a consultation on the phone, or in person? Nancy watches Reagan shake hands with Welden and Deaver. Something’s been decided. ,
(trembling) On the phone. If you don’t mind.
A beautiful, starry night. The house is lit up.
MICHAEL REAGAN (18) drops his backpack on the sofa, as Reagan moves around the room, turning on lights. 44
So this is it? I sleep on the sofa, like a dog?
We don’t have much room, Michael. But it’s good you came. We’re all glad you came, aren’t we, guys? Nancy, Patti, and Ron stand in the doorway, watching.
Yes. Of course we are. Of course. Michael glances at Nancy, uneasily, turns back to Reagan:
But Dad..did Mom tell you?
Sure. We knew you were coming. We just didn’t know it was going to be tonight.
No, not that. Did she tell you I flunked out of that stupid school?

(smiles) Listen, Mike, it’s okay, I never got much in the way of grades, myself. You can try again, here. Go to the public high school. We can even get you some tutoring. Nancy can find you a tutor, can’t you, Mommy?
Yes, of course. Certainly. I'll get the linens.
Patti and Ron follow, whispering:
That guy is my brother? 45
Half-brother. His mother was Daddy’s first wife. And he’s got a sister, Maureen, and the two of you had better be nice, you hear?
I have a sister, too?
The sofa has been made up. As Mike unpacks his backpack, Patti and Ron watch.
Why don’t you live with your real mommy and daddy?
Dad is his Dad, fleabrain.
You’re a fleabrain. Is Maureen going to move in, too?
Maureen’s. married. Actually, she’s married to this really weird guy..Hey, don’t mess with my stuff! Ron’s found a copy of Playboy in the suitcase. Mike snatches it away.
It’s just naked ladies. So what? Patti and Mike laugh. Ron laughs because they’re laughing Reagan appears in the doorway, smiling:
Somebody must have told a good one. They jump. Mike neatly lowers the magazine out of view.
You guys try to keep it down, okay? Mommy’s got a headache. As he goes, Patti turns to Mike with a dark grin: 46
Yeah. And we’re it.
A huge photo of BARRY GOLDWATER—“IN YOUR HEART, YOU KNOW HE’S RIGHT”’—looks down on a room packed with well-heeled SUPPORTERS, as Reagan addresses them from a podium.

We are at war with the most dangerous enemy mankind has faced in his climb from the swamp to the stars..a war for our American way of life. If we lose that war, we’ll have only ourselves to blame... INTERCUT Deaver and Welden standing in back, checking the reaction. Deaver’s impressed.
He’s got them hypnotized..Too bad he’s only an actor, huh?
Yeah. I wish he’d mention Goldwater. Nancy, Betsy, Arthur Bloomingdale and Holmes Tuttle are sitting at a nearby table, listening intently.

You and I have a rendezvous with destiny. We can preserve for our children this, the last best hope of man on earth, or we can sentence them to take the first step into a thousand years of darkness. The audience applauds thunderously. Betsy leans over. to Nancy, whispers:
Did you talk to Carol? What did she say? Nancy whispers into her ear. As the applause fades, A WOM stands up in the audience, calling to Reagan:
Mr. Reagan! Mr. Reagan! Have you registered as a Republican, yet? 47
(grin) Well,.no, I haven't yet..but I intend to.
It just so happens that I’m a registrar. As everyone laughs in shock, she walks down the aisle and places a registration form on the podium in front of him. He signs it.
Now, where was I? The audience rises to their feet, cheering. Reagan acknowledges them. He finds Nancy in the sea of cheering faces, and smiles.

Almost everyone is gone. The dance band is playing one last song. Nancy and Reagan are standing near the exit, talking to ADMIRERS. Betsy is with them. On the other side of the room, Ben Welden, Alfred Bloomingdale, and Holmes Tuttle are sitting at a table, talking quietly.
Listen, Ben. Holmes and I are ready to write checks right now...
Mr. Goldwater thanks you both.
We’ve already given to Goldwater. We’re talking about Ronald Reagan.

The governor’s race is going to be wide open next year. The party in California’s in a shambles. We have a feeling that he might be the man to bring it together. Mike Deaver arrives with a beer, sits down.
- Yeah, but can you really run an actor for Governor? 48
Gentlemen, this is Mike Deaver. He can get anybody elected to anything. The excitement at the table rises, perceptibly.
Reagan’s not an actor, he’s a movie-star. Besides, it’s good that he doesn’t know anything about Government. It makes him more a man of the people.
And since he’s a movie star, everybody knows him. Running Reagan will cost half what it would cost to run somebody that nobody's ever heard of.
Listen, Alfred. I’ve been talking to Ronnie about running, for years. I’ve talked until I was blue in the face. He's not interested.

Well..Maybe you’ve been talking to the wrong Reagan. They all look over at Nancy, who is pulling Reagan onto t dance floor. Silently, they watch them begin to dance. ANGLE - Reagan and Nancy dance well, together. Perfectly matched. He pulls her close, gives her a tender kiss.
Congratulations, Mr. Republican.
(teasing) Did you pay that woman to come up and register me? Nancy laughs, slyly.
Oh, Ronnie. I wish I had. They laugh, as they continue to slow-dance.
EXT. REAGANS’ HOUSE - PACIFIC PALISADES - NIGHT SUPER: “1964” A few cars in the driveway. Walter Cronkite’s voice reporting Goldwater’s defeat by LBJ; the worst in electio history.
Reagan watches tv, while eating jellybeans out of a jar. Nearby, are Deaver, Welden, and Betsy and Alfred Bloomingdale. Grim. The maid is emptying ash trays.
Four more years of LBJ.
He's going to double taxes, you watch.
Yup. By the time the Democrats are done, there’1l be no corporations left, in this country. We'll all be bankrupt. (pause) Ronnie, I’m telling you. You're our only hope.
What makes you think I could be Governor? I’ve never even played one. They laugh. EXT. REAGANS’ POOL - CONTINUING Alfred Holmes talks to Nancy in the shadows, by the pool.

Nancy, we want to put your husband in the Governor’s seat, and keep him there for 8 years. Then we’re going to put him in the Presidency for another 8 years. By the time he’s done, Communism will be dead, the Republican Party reunited, and “conservative” won’t be a dirty word, anymore. 50
Holmes, he’s told you and told you..He doesn’t want to do it. He likes his life the way it is.
Yeah, but do you? Nancy turns silent, wary.

Sure, it’s nice being the wife of a movie star. But think what it would be like to be the wife of the Governor of California. (pause) First Lady of California—sounds pretty good, doesn’t it? There you'll be, in the Governor’s mansion—
It’s a dump.
Then we’ll get you someplace nicer, somewhere right in Sacramento—
I hate Sacramento. Holmes pauses again.

Nancy, listen..Ronnie’s not the only one who can unite the party. So can you. He’s the Governor, but you’re the power behind the throne. And with all that power, all that money..You’1l have your own projects, but you can also influence your husband’s decisions on the economy, the welfare state, and the future of California. You’1l be the social and political center of power. I tell you-comparatively speaking, it makes Hollywood look like Tobacco Road. She turns, without a word, and goes into the house. He slowly follows. INT. REAGANS’ LIVING ROOM - NIGHT | Everyone's laughing, as Nancy comes back into the room. sits on the arm of his chair, putting her arm around him. 51
How’s Ron?
Fast asleep.
Nancy, we want to form a “Friends of Ronald Reagan” Committee. What do you say?
I told them, you and I are already friends. Nancy laughs. Holmes appears in the doorway, re-lights hi cigar while the conversation continues:

I don’t know. It means turning everything upside down..especially your life, Nancy. Your life will never be the same. All eyes turn to Nancy. She smiles mysteriously, and give him a kiss on top of his head.

Oh God, Ronnie..I’m tired of fighting it, aren’t you? These people need you. California needs you. (pause) And besides, I have a very special friend who says you’d make a great Governor. Reagan turns to the others, smiling:
Isn‘t she the greatest?

(then) Okay, gentlemen. Where do we start? INT. REAGANS’ DEN - NIGHT The den is filled with NEW FACES (CAMPAIGN AIDES) making posters, stuffing envelopes, on the phone, etc. One of the aides comes out..Bumps into little Ron in the hallway, who’s dancing to his own silent music... 52 Keeps going into the kitchen, where he opens the fridge starts rummaging for food. A PUBLICITY STILL OF THE FAMIL EXCLUDING MIKE AND. MAUREEN (“VOTE FOR REAGAN!”) is taped the refrigerator door. Nearby, Nancy is trying to talk on the phone and deal wit an angry Patti at the same time:
(into the phone) I know he’s about to flunk out..I’ve gotten him tutoring, but it doesn’t seem to help..
I’m not going to boarding school, and you can’t make me.
Patti, I’m talking to Mike’s teacher—
I’1l run away! I will!
Patti, go to your room! Now! Patti kicks the refrigerator, and runs off in tears. Nanc turns to the cupboard, takes out a bottle of Valium, take one. Holds onto the cupboard to steady her nerves.

Do you have anymore mayo? INT. NANCY’S BATHROOM - PALISADES HOUSE Patti sneaks in, and quietly opens Nancy’s medicine cabinet. It’s full of prescription drugs. She takes down bottle, pours some pills into her hand, stuffs them in he pocket. EXT. MIKE’S SCHOOL - DAY Mike is sitting on the curb, tightly coiled, as Nancy drives up with Ron and Patti in the back seat. He climbs in. The car roars away from the curb.
Nancy turns to Mike. Her hands clenched to the steering wheel. In the back, Patti is asleep on the seat. 53
So what happened?
I didn’t start it. The other guy hit me.
You're getting a reputation. Listen, Mike..Your father and I want to help you, but we’ve come to a dead end. Either you start living up to the Reagan name, or get out.
You want me to leave?
Unless you shape up.
You don’t want me, anyway. You never did.

I’m not your mother. I don’t have to want you. Go back to your real mother and your real father..whoever they were: The words are barely out of her mouth, when Nancy wishes she could stuff them back in. Too late. The damage is done. They ride, in silence.
Mike slams in from outside, stomps thru the house, and ou the door to the pool. A moment later, Nancy comes in with Patti. She goes to th den, where Reagan is meeting with Deaver and Welden.
Ronnie, may I speak to you for a moment?
Sure, Mommy. Reagan comes out. He’s overwhelmed, too.
Mermie called. She’s on her way here. She needs a place to stay for a few days. 54
Why?
She won’t say. But she’s leaving her husband. I told her she could help out with the campaign.
Oh God. Okay, and here’s some news for you-Mike got into another fight at school. And I..I said some things I shouldn’t have said. (then) I've had it, Ronnie. I really have. He’s got to go.
Where? Where will he go?
Anywhere. Home to Jane. For God’s sake, he’s old enough to live on his own.
But I like having him here—
Ronnie, I can’t deal with him, and take care of Ron, and get Patti off to boarding school and besides, all these people—we don’t have any privacy, none at all—
She’s on the verge of tears. Reagan kisses, hugs her.
Okay, fine, I’11 tell him. Nancy can see his reluctance.
Never mind, you don’t have to. I'll take care of it. He already thinks I'ma monster. I am a monster.

How could you possibly be a monster? Come on, Nancy-pants. Don’t cry, it’1l put lines in your face. Smile. Smile. “She tries to smile. He kisses her. DOORBELL. Before they can move, Ron runs to the door, and opens it. 55
Maureen (24) is standing on the threshold, with a suitcas
Hi, are you Ron? I’m your big sister Maureen.

Nancy is getting linens out of the hall-closet. She heads towards the den... passing the kitchen, where Reagan, Welden and Deaver are sitting around. the kitchen table, talking... checking the patio where Mike sulks, while Ron and Patti are playing cards... AS NANCY PASSES, Patti turns to Ron and whispers:
She’s getting rid of me, and she’s getting rid of Mike. The next one to get rid of is you. Little Ron’s eyes grow big.
Nancy sets the linens on the sofa. Maureen is setting up her things on a shelf.
These are for you. Since Mike’s on the sofa, I imagine you’1l have to sleep on the floor.
Fine.
I want to say something here. Girl-talk. Maureen turns and looks at her.
What is it?
Since your father is running for public office..and you’re in the middle of a divorce..I really think it’s best if you 56  would exempt yourself from taking part in his campaign.
(astonished) Dad was divorced, too—

Yes, but the voters already know that. Frankly, Mermie, if you want to help your father, the best thing you can do is stay away. Nancy is about to pat Maureen on the shoulder, when she sees a ferocious bruise on Maureen's upper arm. She stare at it for several moments--then turns, and walks out. Maureen stares after her, darkly.

A chartered bus smokes in the driveway, a banner on its side reads “Reagan for Governor”. Nancy and Reagan come o of the house, accompanied by aides carrying their suitcases. Reagan helps Nancy onto the bus. Maureen is nowhere to be seen. Welden and Deaver are talking.
We could cover a lot more ground if he’d fly.
He's afraid of it. Been afraid of it since he was a kid. Deaver looks at the bus, and sighs.
It’s filled with CHEERING VOLUNTEERS. Reagan grins at the 57

Until last night, I thought I was agreeing to do something that would last only until November, and then I’d go back to private life. But then Nancy said to me, “What if you win?” (mock-horror) I said, “Wait a minute! If I win this damn thing, I’m out of show business! And I’m in politics!” Everybody roars with laughter. A SERIES OF SCENES: Reagan and Nancy on the campaign trai Receptions in homes and drab hotels. Endless hand-shaking Welden and Deaver always at Reagan’s side.
Governor Pat Brown in a commercial, talking to a classroo of kids:

I’m running against an actor, and you know who shot Lincoln, don’t you? EXT. SMALL CALIFORNIA. TOWN -— DAY The Reagan bus stops at an American Legion Hall, where a CROWD is waiting. They burst into cheers, as an exhausted Reagan gets out, smiling and waving. He plunges into the crowd, shaking hands, bantering (ad lib) as Welden tries to keep him moving. Nancy follows, looking nervously at A GROUP OF STUDENT PROTESTORS at the edge of the crowd.
REAGAN'S A FASCIST! REAGAN’S A FASCIST! (ETC. )
An object flies out of the group, intended to hit Reagan the head. He catches it--an orange--throws it back.
This thing isn’t ripe. And neither are you! The crowd laughs. Reagan shouts to the students: 58
And you know what? If I had any doubts that I’m doing the right thing, I just lost. them! So when I’m your next Governor... His supporters cheer..the students boo...
The first thing I’m going to do is clean up the mess on our college campuses! A turmoil of cheers and jeers. Supporters and students exchange angry shouts. A scuffle breaks out.
A posh private school for girls..Horse stables, etc...
VERY LOUD MUSIC: Rolling Stones ("19 Nervous Breakdown”) GIRLS (age 12 - 16) running in and out of their rooms, shrieking, dancing. Another night at boarding school.
Cigarette smoke swirls in the student lounge, where a big hand-made sign (“Vote for Pat Brown”) covers almost an entire wall. A GROUP OF A DOZEN GIRLS IN HIPPIE GARB sit, glued. to the tv.
And in California, Ronald Reagan has won the gubernatorial election by nearly a million votes, taking 55 of the 58 counties in that state... A GENERAL GROAN. ONE GIRL bursts into tears (Patti, 14).
Jesus Christ. We’re all screwed.
Look out, everybody. Hitler’s just been elected Governor. A titter goes around the room. Another girl rolls over in Patti's lap, and hugs her:
It’s okay, Patti. We still love you. 59
Laughter. Patti shrinks into her seat, still crying.
Michael hangs out with sailboat-racing buddies as he star at the bar tv, which is showing pictures of Reagan Headquarters filled with cheering crowds. He and his friend whoop and holler.
Reagan and Nancy holding each other, as their AIDES, including Ben Welden, slap each other on the back. Ron watches from the corner, reeking of loneliness. The death chant of VOICES CALLING (OC):
RONNIE! (etc.)
The camera-lights are blinding, as Reagan pulls Nancy through the crowd to the podium. He’s holding up his hand for silence, but the CROWD IS CHANTING FASTER AND FASTER:
RONNIE! RONNIE! RONNIE (etc.) The chanting builds almost to the point of hysteria, then

EXT. SACRAMENTO CAPITOL STEPS —- A marble statue of the Holy Virgin looks down on a solemn ceremony waiting to begin. Reagan and Nancy stand before robed JUSTICE, heads bowed. Nancy is holding an old, tape Bible-Reagan’s mother’s Bible. A group of SPECTATORS shivers, as well as Loyal and Edith Davis, and little Ron, who’s half-asleep, being held up b Maureen. Nearby, the all-white members of Reagan’s administration—including ED MEESE, (we'll meet him later) Ben Welden, and Mike Deaver. When the TOLLING stops, Nancy hands the Bible to the Justice. Reagan puts one hand on it, and raises the other repeating after the Justice: 60
I, Ronald Wilson Reagan, do solemnly swear... ANGLE - Welden and Deaver watching, as the oath continues Deaver tries to restrain a yawn of exhaustion, whispers:
For the love of Pete, why did we have to do this at midnight?

It’s her “special friend”. (off Deaver’s look) Some astrologer. Mommy talks to her on the phone almost every day. Welden nods to Nancy, who is standing next to Reagan, looking at him with so much adoration, it’s almost scary.

The astrologer said it had to be right after midnight. When Jupiter was rising. The same time they crown Kings. And one more thing—it had to be in a part of the Capital that had never been used for a swearing-in before. Deaver stares at him, wishing he could laugh. As Reagan finishes the oath, he turns to Nancy, gives her a kiss.
By the way, Mike, I’m giving you a special job. From now on, you’re on Mommy Watch.
DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: Music: the Beatles’ “Eleanor Rigby” over..LBJ grins, shows his gallbladder scar to the press. Mohammed Ali indicted for refusing to be drafted..Crowds Viet Nam protesters...
SUPER: “1967”. An explosion of shouts, chants, jeers from STUDENT DEMONSTRATORS. As Reagan comes out of the hall, escorted POLICE, he’s immediately met by another mob: the MEDIA.
I’ve just put the Trustees of this University on notice. The people of this state are sick and tired of sit-ins and walk-outs. It’s time we had a few throw- outs!
Go back to Hollywood, Bonzo!
The People put me here, son! I don’t know what drugs you’re on, but starting right now, you're going to obey the rules, or get out! Students hissing and booing. FLASHBULBS POP.
Reagan’s angry face beneath a headline: “Reagan fires Berkeley President: Vows Deep Cuts in State Spending”.
The mansion is a classic wedding-cake Victorian on a busy street. Traffic booms noisily past as...
Nancy follows Mike Deaver into the Governor’s mansion for the first time. The walls are peeling, the rug is torn. Dust hangs in the air. Outside, TRAFFIC ROARS PAST. 62

(grimly) It certainly is historic, isn’t it? As if to punctuate this remark, ANOTHER TRUCK RUMBLES PAS EXT. REAGANS’ HOUSE - POOL - PACIFIC PALISADES - DAY Nancy beside the pool, watching Ron swim, as she talks to Carol Ryder on the phone:
It’s a fire-trap. We'd be asleep, the wiring would catch fire, and we'd all be burned alive.

text: You already know you don’t want to live there. Use your power.
But what about the press? The Governor’s family has always, always lived there...
What do they say in Hollywood? Buckle your seat-belt. It’s going to be a bumpy ride.
Nancy takes a sip of her wine, and leans forward to Betsy Bloomingdale, furious:
So then Mike Deaver says, “Why don’t you fix it up? It can be your own little project, like Jackie Kennedy fixing up the White House.”
Only Jackie Kennedy had a budget.

Exactly. I’m not going to have Ronnie living in a flea-trap. We’re going to rent a nice house, a beautiful house where we can entertain people from the industry, and ambassadors and all the rest of our friends, and anyone who doesn’t like it 63 \veisit”  can go to hell, and I don’t care how much it costs.
You don’t?
(smile) Well, that brings me to you. Betsy smiles back, and turns to a PASSING WAITER:

Waiter. Get me a phone, would you? (back to Nancy) Alfred and Holmes Tuttle got you into this mess. They should get you out. A PAUNCHY MAN IN A BAD SUIT is standing outside the door with a zoom lens, quietly taking pictures.

| Two headlines (“Fancy Nancy Turns Up Her Nose at Govern Mansion” and "Nancy Eats Out, While Hubbie Cuts School Lunches”) are being prepared with a picture of Nancy and Betsy at lunch. AN EDITOR is looking at them. He picks “Fancy Nancy...”

Go with this one. EXT. REAGANS’ RENTED. HOUSE ~ SACRAMENTO - DAY A garage door rises, and the Governor’s limo emerges from the dark, heading down the driveway. A SMALL CROWD OF DEMONSTRATORS are gathered on the lawn o the Reagans’ magnificent rented house. Nancy and little Ron are in the back seat. He’s got his school bag. Suddenly, out of nowhere, A TOMATO splats against the window. Nancy and Ron scream, and grab each other in fright.

BACK TO THE NEWSPAPER EDITOR'S OFFICE - as he picks a picture of a single, black Welfare mom with her children, matches it with a headline (“Welfare is a Cancer, Says Reagan”) and hands it to his ASSISTANT. 64
Go with this. JUMP CUT - The editor holds up a mock-up of another front page with another headline: “Reagan Issues Biggest Tax Hi in U.S. History”...
This one. JUMP CUT - a picture of a mental hospital stamped “Closed
Yeah. Perfect.
Police mug shot of a black man.

This is Aaron Mitchell. Convicted cop- killer on Death Row in San Quentin. Governor Brown upheld the sentence before he left office, and both the state and national Supreme Courts have denied a stay of execution. He’s scheduled to die tomorrow night. Mitchell's face projected on the wall of the Gubernatoria Cabinet Room-a dingy room with a long table, torn rug, an cigar burns on the furniture. Reagan and Mike Deaver are at the table, going through Mitchell’s file. ED MEESE, (40's), Reagan’s clemency secretary, continues:
He has his final mercy hearing this afternoon. After that, Governor, it’s up to you.
Even Pat Brown said he should die. And he was against the death penalty. Reagan hands Mitchell’s file back to Meese. 65
(grimly) Thanks, Ed. If the law says Aaron Mitchell has to die, then I agree. Pause.
His mother is in the hallway. She’s got her attorney with her, and a helluva lot of reporters.
(nodding) It’s a sorry mess. Listen, Ed, I’d talk to her myself, but I’ve got to get on a plane in 20 minutes for a meeting in Los Angeles. Can you talk to her?
(surprised) Yes, sir.

You might want to use the security entrance, sir. Reagan stands up, ending the meeting. Welden turns on the lights, and Mitchell’s projection disappears. As Reagan and Deaver leave, Meese turns to Ben Welden:
What’s the meeting in Los Angeles?
(sigh) Academy Awards. ON MEESE’S INCREDULOUS FACE -
AARON MITCHELL’S MOTHER emerges, being held up by her ATTORNEY, sobbing in agony:

Why, Jesus, why? Why? Why? 66  MRS. MITCHELL’S ATTORNEY Ronald Reagan doesn’t care about people like us. He’s running for the Presidency... EXT. REAGANS’ RENTED HOUSE - SACRAMENTO - NIGHT Outside, AN ENORMOUS GROUP OF DEMONSTRATORS are gathered the dark, holding candles and ringing handbells, singing:

“We shall overcome We shall overcome...(etc.”) They hold up signs: “Ronald Reagan—No Academy Award for Legal Murder”; “California’s First Execution Since 1963”. INT. REAGANS’ RENTED HOUSE - CONTINUING Little Ron watching from his bedroom window in the dark. The door opens, and Nancy enters in her nightgown.
Ron. Get back into bed.
What are they singing?
It’s nothing. A song, that’s all. She lifts him back into bed, covers him with the blankets
But why are they mad at us? What'd we do?
Shhh..they’re not mad at us. Close your eyes. Sleep. Everything’s fine. Nancy kisses his forehead, smoothes his hair one last tim and leaves the room.
Nancy emerges from Ron’s bedroom, passes Mike Deaver and NANCY REYNOLDS, her press secretary, hiding behind a curtain, looking out the window at the demonstrators. 67

(hissing, furious) Tell me..What gives those..people..the right to terrify an 8-year-old boy? INT. REAGAN’S STUDY - SACRAMENTO HOUSE - CONTINUING Reagan is in his study, with REVEREND DONN MOOMAW, a born again former football star. They’re on their knees, prayi in front of a picture of a blonde, blue-eyed Jesus.
My heart can’t be wrong, can it? If I love Jesus and follow his teachings, I can’t be wrong, can I?
You're not wrong, Governor...
Aaron Mitchell is going to die, and it’s because of me. I could have saved him..
No one can save Aaron Mitchell from the sin he committed.
(anguished) Why do I feel as if it’s my fault?
Let Jesus carry your burden, Governor. That’s all he asks-to carry your burden.

head_text.subj: OUTSIDE, A CHURCH BELL BEGINS TO TOLL. A CRY OF AGONY GOE

text: (choking) Why don’t they ring those bells every time there’s a murder? Moomaw begins to pray:
We pray for your will to be revealed, oh Lord... 68
We pray for your will to be revealed, oh Lord...

We pray for Armageddon, when, according to your will, the dark forces of the world will be defeated by a leader from the West, who will be revealed as the Antichrist. He, too, will fall, and then Jesus Christ will triumph in the creation of a new heaven and a new earth...
Amen.

THE PRISON BELL TOLLS as the gates of San Quentin part, allowing AN AMBULANCE to rumble slowly through A SMALL CROWD which is holding up signs (“Killing a Cop is Worse than Killing 3,000 Vietnamese Peasants?”; “Hang Down Your Head, Black Aaron—Po’Boy You Gonna Die”). AUDIBLE SOBBING as the ambulance drives off into the night.
The endless California sun is shining, as Nancy escorts journalist JOAN DIDION into the back yard.
My life began when I met Ronnie..It really did.He is my hero. She looks up, and sees Ron appear in the back door.
Skipper, you’re home! Come on down here, honey, I want you to meet somebody! Ron was sneaking away. He lamely turns, and comes out.
This is Joan Didion. She’s writing an article about us. Can you say hello?
‘Lo. Nancy smiles as hard as she can, painfully aware of Didion's critical stare, and continues: 69 Ne”
How’s Chuck’s cold?
Chuck doesn’t have a cold.
(trying) Chuck doesn’t have a cold?
No. Bruce has braces.
Bruce has braces?
Bye. With that, Ron runs back into the house. Nancy resumes walking, steering Didion toward the garden:

I don’t believe in being an absentee mother. I just don’t. INT. RON’S BEDROOM - CONTINUING CLASSICAL MUSIC playing loud. Ron is dancing around his room with joyous enthusiasm. Leaping, pirouetting, etc.

You lying, cheating, nasty little bitch. Worming your way into my house..Smiling at me..pretending everything’s oh-so-nice..Such a nice house..Such beautiful children..so nice to meet you, Mrs. Reagan..and your movies”..Blah Blah Blah..Talk about me having a phony smile, what about you? You’re not a writer, you’re an untalented liar. Hack! That’s what you are, a hack! REAGAN POKES HIS HEAD INTO THE BATHROOM AND SEES Nancy in the tub, up to her neck in bubbles. She startles.
Ronnie! Reagan sniffs the air suspiciously: 70
Mmm. Bath-oil. And lots of it. You must be pretty upset.

Oh Ronnie..the article by that bitch Joan Didion came out today..she hates me. She positively hates me. She said I'm “living . in some daydream circa 1948”! And you know what else she said? She said the way I mother the children, it’s positively scary. She even made fun of the way I look at you! She called it “the Gaze”!
Oh, she’s probably jealous.
That‘s what I said! I told her, she’s probably jealous! (lamely) I mean, here. In the tub. I told her. He laughs, goes out.

That‘s what I always liked about you, Nancy-pants! You’ve got guts! MOVIE - BLACK AND WHITE - “KNUTE ROCKNE; ALL AMERICAN” MUSIC: VIOLINS as Reagan (George Gipp), lies in a hospita bed, dying. His coach, Pat O’Brien (“Rock”) stands nearby

Rock...ssomeday when the team’s up against it..when the breaks are beating the boys..ask them to go in there with all they've got..win just one for the Gipper.. INT. REAGANS’ DEN - CONTINUING AS MUSIC SOARS..SUPER: “1968” Nancy and Reagan are watching the movie on a screen, eati Popcorn, tears in their eyes. Reagan whispers..like Gipp:
I’ve got to do it, Mommy. 721
Do what?
| Just once. I’ve got to run for the Presidency at least once. Pause. Nancy turns to him in disbelief.
What?
Some of the boys think I should run. They did a poll, they think I can get more than 60% of the conservative vote.
Ronnie..you can’t run for the Presidency. You just got elected Governor.
Do you think it’s too soon?
Yes, I think it’s too soon. It’s way too soon. Ronnie. (he’s not listening) Ronnie.
Nancy corners Mike Deaver in his office. She’s mad.
Who told Ronnie he could win the nomination in ‘68?
(hastily) . It wasn’t me. It was the polls.
Mike, it’s too early. He doesn’t have enough experience. Not only that, he can’t possibly win. Nixon has it sewn up.
But you’ve got to admit, he’s got a lot of people excited. Nancy looks out the door to make sure no one’s around. 72
It’s more than that. My friend.my friend \ says it’s not going to work. He'll lose by 7 an enormous margin.
Well, if it doesn’t happen, so what? He’ll still be the Governor of California. He can run again in ‘72. It’s a joke. Nancy ignores it.

Mike, you don’t get it. He'll have lost. Lost. Don’t you see? (intensely) Ronald Reagan does not lose elections. Ronald Reagan is not a loser. Her vehemence drives Deaver into. silence. EXT. ORME CAMPUS — NIGHT INT. PATTI’S DORM ROOM - CONTINUING Patti and her boyfriend, GARY (18), making out in her roo She comes up for air long enough to say:
If we're going to do it, Gary, we’ve got to do it now.
But Patti, what if they come after us?
I’ve got it all figured out. My brother Mike’s working in Phoenix. I'll get him to sign me out for a weekend visit. By the time they know I’m gone, we’1ll be in Canada.
Speedboats are being fixed in the background, as Mike, in mechanic’s overalls, talks to Patti on the phone:
(into the phone) Patti, this is crazy.
INTERCUT Patti at school, on a payphone: PATTI . I love him. He loves me. He'll go straight to Vietnam unless you help me.
- But you’re asking me to lie for you...
I’m asking you to be my brother. Please, Mike. Please. Help me.
Okay, okay... ‘ He hangs up. Worried.

A DELEGATION-the Headmaster and his wife, faculty members students—are waiting as two cars drive in through the gat The Secret Service gets out of the first car. Reagan gets out of the back seat of the second car, leavi Nancy and the DRIVER inside. PATTI SITTING UNDER A TREE NEARBY in classic hippie drag. She gets up and crosses to Reagan, longing to hug him.
(grinning) Hi, Shorty. We just happened to be in the neighborhood...
Oh Daddy. I’m so sorry.

It‘s alright. All’s well that ends well. Thanks to Mike. Now get in the car. I’ve got to talk to the Headmaster, and see if I can keep him from throwing you out. INT. REAGAN’S CAR - CONTINUING Nancy is in the back seat, privacy window separating her from the driver, a.c. running. Patti opens the door, and climbs in. Pause. 74
Just tell me..are you pregnant?
(a harsh laugh) You know what, Mom? We never even did it. (off Nancy's reaction) I’m still a virgin. Cross my lying little heart. Nancy struggles not to lose it.
Go change your clothes. Your father’s taking us to dinner.
I’m not changing. If he wants to take me out, then I’m going like this.
Don’t argue. Go.
No. This is it. Take it or leave it.
Why do you do this to me? Why do you have to fight me?
Why do you hate me?
I don’t hate you.
You've always hated me. You’ve hated me since I was a little girl. Go on, hit me. You can’t hurt me, anymore. Nancy slaps her. Patti reels, comes back up defiant.
The Secret Service Agents heard the slap, and exchange a glance. In the b.g., Reagan approaches. INT. REAGANS’ CAR - CONTINUING As Reagan climbs into the car, he turns to Patti: 75
So, did Mommy tell you the news?
No. Nancy obliges:
They want your father to run for President.
Daddy, are you serious? You just started being Governor.
(smiles) That’s what Mommy said. At least you two agree on something. The two cars drive away, vanishing in a SWIRLING CLOUD OF DUST which becomes...

SUPER: “1968” More images of smoke and fire: a bonfire at an anti-war rally..tear gas swirling in Detroit as blacks riot..RFK d in a hotel kitchen..Martin Luther King iying on a motel balcony in Memphis..Smoke shrouds the Capitol Building... And A BATTERY OF CAMERAS FLASH as Reagan announces:

I seek the nomination for the highest office in our land because I have no choice. Everything we hold dear—the American ideals that have made us the envy of the world—-is under attack. It’s time to fight back. He’s standing amid a crowd on THE CAPITOL STEPS (SACRAMENTO). Nancy murmurs to Deaver and Welden, stonily
It’s not his time. He’s got Saturn in his | tenth house. He’s going to lose. And it’s you people who pushed him into it. Welden steps back, mutters to Deaver, sarcastically: 76
Alas..Who knows what’s in the stars? Nancy doesn’t hear: she’s watching Reagan with a look of utter doom on her face.

MC’S VOICE Ladies and gentlemen, the next President of the United States, Richard Milhouse Nixon. RICHARD AND PAT NIXON, TRICIA AND JULIE enter, smiling broadly. Nixon thrusts his arms into the air in victory.
77 aa NSasast”
