Are you ready?
Shoot . Ron switches on a tape-recorder. The reel begins to turn.
So, Dad. I mean Governor Reagan. As you prepare to leave office, what do you think is the biggest achievement of your administration?
Are you speaking as a reporter, or as my son?
Dad. Come on. It’s the school paper.

Okay, let’s see..Well, I know people hate to hear this..but the state of California has finally been forced to become fiscally responsible..which meant that, like it or not, we had to end the free lunch that a lot of our citizens had come to expect.
Yeah, but you closed down two-thirds of the state mental hospitals, and all those people ended up on the street. (off Reagan’s look of surprise) Dad, I’m not stupid. 78
(smiles) No, you’re not. But I have much more faith in the resilience of the American people than you do. They always pull themselves up by their own bootstraps. eat
But you raised taxes more than any other Governor in United States history. I mean, you’re a Republican, you're supposed to be against raising taxes.

Well, I've got a theory about economics. If the rich have more money to spend on buying things and building businesses, it will naturally end up helping the poor people. It’s called “trickle-down”. Pause. Ron is turning cautious.
You want to run for President again, don’t you?
Now, Ron..You know me better than that. Reagan laughs. Ron doesn’t. He’s worried.
What if you turn into another Richard Nixon? Reagan is surprised. Silent for several moments.

Listen, Ron. I go to bed at night with the knowledge that I’ve done my best to see and hope that these people..that I’ve directly appointed..meet the standards that I want them to meet. But there can be someone..while I’m sleeping..doing something he shouldn't do, and it will break over my head. Silence, as Ron tries to figure this one out.
So are you saying, you are or you aren’t going to run for President in ‘76? Reagan’s eyes twinkle, as he answers:

Ron, I tell you from the bottom of my heart..I have utterly and absolutely no ambitions to be President in 1976. INT. NANCY’S BEDROOM - DAY Nancy sitting on her bed in her dressing gown. She swallo a Valium as she talks into the phone.

It’s the strangest thing..In the midst of all this packing and leaving..and not knowing what’s going to happen to us, once Ronnie leaves office..I keep thinking about my real father. Isn’t that funny? I haven’t thought about him in so long.
Sometimes, as we get older, our childhood doesn’t fade away. It gets stronger.
Yes. Yes. That’s it..I can’t stop thinking about him..wondering why he left..Why? Why did he leave? PAN TO A FADED PHOTO OF A MAN (1920's) on the desk.

It’s a dance class. Ron is one guy out of two in a class full. of girls, but he’s dancing harder than anybody else He’s dancing so hard, it’s as if he’s trying to work something out—some unresolved anger. The TEACHER stops hi
Ron. Ron. Slow down. You’re pushing too hard. Ron tries to slow down, but he keeps dancing and pushing. 80
Do you hear me? You’re going to hurt yourself. Stop. Everybody stop. Ron, I want to talk to you. Everybody stops. Ron follows the teacher to the corner.
You tell your folks you want to dance? (Ron shakes his head) Why not, are you ashamed?
(aggressively) What do you think?

You've got talent, Ron. Tell them, before you hurt yourself so badly that you can’t dance. (then) . Okay, kids. Start over. Positions. Music. The music begins again. The dancing resumes. INT. PATTI’S HOUSE (TOPANGA CANYON) - AFTERNOON MUSIC: SOMEONE COMPOSING ON AN ELECTRIC GUITAR. All aroun anti-war posters, mood lamps, incense, etc. Patti (22) is lying on the sofa, smoking a joint as she stares at the front page of the paper, which features a photograph of Gerry Ford.

Gerry Ford is a real argument for birth control. Gerry Ford..Richard Nixon..Not to mention my father. The pigs have taken over, you know? Bernie? Bernie? She goes into the kitchen, where BERNIE (24) is sitting o the kitchen counter, playing an electric guitar as he watches soup boil on the stove.
Jesus, Bernie. You’re supposed to be watching the soup.
I am. 81 “au”  Patti turns off the stove, and puts her hand on Bernie’s strings to stop the music. Pause.

The political machine is bent on destroying us. The only thing we can do is lay down our bodies in front of it. Sacrifice ourselves, if we have to. (pause) Even if nobody else will stand up for their conscience, I will.

Reagan swimming down, down through dark water. Panicky, searching. HIS HEART POUNDING. He sees a child’s hand emerging from the black. He grabs it, and pulls—it’s a CHILD’S BODY, EYES OPEN, DROWNED. Reagan SCREAMS UNDERWATER. INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - TWILIGHT Reagan sits bolt upright in bed, in a terror. Nancy reach out to him:
Bad dream?
Somebody was drowning... She pulls him down again, stroking his hair, consoling hi as she has, a hundred times:
It’s okay. Nobody’s drowning. We’re all here.

Reagan, shirtless, chopping wood. He’s strong. He can spl a log with one chop. He pauses, wipes the sweat from his brow, looks out over the mountains. It’s so beautiful. Nancy sits on a log nearby, drinking a cup of coffee.
Sometimes I think, screw politics. I was made for chopping trees..and dredging ponds..and fixing the roof... 82
There’1l1 be plenty of time for that, later. After you're done being President, and we’re lying around, eating bonbons and building Presidential libraries.
You’re a troublemaker, you know that?
Me? I’m the one who's kept you from messing your life up.

Hey. Watch your mouth. He starts toward her. She runs away, laughing. INT. REAGANS’ HOUSE - REAGANS’ OFFICE - DAY SUPER: “1975” Reagan is on head-set, talking into the mic, finishing hi weekly radio address.

Status quo. That’s Latin for the mess we're in. (beat) Well, that’s it for this week, folks. Just remember: to err is human—it takes a government computer to really louse things up. See you next week. He turns off the mic and looks up, as Nancy sticks her he into the room.
Guess who's here? Mike Deaver sticks his head in, behind her.

Well, it had an effect on me. It scared the crap out of me. Because he brings out the dark side in the old man. He does. They’re interrupted by Patti and Ron coming out, whisperi to each other. As soon as Patti and Ron see them, they fa silent. Deaver, Baker, and Meese stand up, and smile.
Hi, kids. We’ve got some paperwork for your dad to sign.
Now? In Intensive Care?
The country needs to know that he’s still in charge.
Besides, it’s good for him. He needs to know that he’s still in charge, too, don’t you think? FOLLOW PATTI AND RON down the hall, looking back over the shoulders, as the Troika go into Reagan’s room:

Those guys scare me. INT. REAGAN’S HOSPITAL ROOM - DAY Nancy is putting some last minute. rouge on Reagan’s chee as the PHOTOGRAPHER gets set up, and Deaver, Baker, and Meese position the papers for Reagan to sign. 139
Ronnie, I’m just going to give you a little color...
(to the photographer) See? The President’s fine. Fine. Nancy puts the pen in Reagan’s hand, and holds it, slowly writing his name. Reagan smiles for the camera. FLASH.
A MOB OF MEDIA outside. The Presidential limos.

The usual phalanx of Secret Service clears a path through Hospital Personnel, who break into cheers, as... Reagan appears, walking with difficulty, leaning on Nancy and Agent Parr’s arms. Reagan’s wearing a bright red cardigan. They’re all smiling. As he approaches the exit door, Dr. Aaron and the medical team are waiting to say goodbye.
Take it easy, now. Try not to overwork. You sure you don’t want a wheelchair?
He refuses. He absolutely refuses.
Every KGB agent in the Kremlin is going to be watching, to see if America has an invalid for a President. Well, they’re in for a disappointment. Laughter.
As Reagan emerges, smiling cheerfully, like a man in perfect health, the reporters start shouting questions:
How are you, Mr. President? How are you feeling? (etc.) 140

Ready to go back to work, and give you fellows something to write about! As he and Nancy head for their limousine, the Media start to applaud. Among them is Bill Shelby, looking critically at his colleagues, as they continue to cheer.
TWO US AIRFORCE JETS shooting down two Libyan Jets. They burst into flames, and crash into a calm blue sea (the Gu of Sidra). FADE UP: THE TICKING OF A CLOCK.

INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - NIGHT The clock on the bedside table is ticking: 4:24 a.m. Reag and Nancy are fast asleep, when the phone rings sharply, and loudly. Reagan sleeps through it. Nancy opens her eye reaches over his sleeping body to pick it up:
Yes. INTERCUT BETWEEN REAGANS’ BEROOM AND ED MEESE, IN HIS WHI HOUSE OFFICE.
Nancy, it’s Ed. I'm sorry to wake you up. We have a little bit of a crisis. i j i Nancy covers the mouthpiece with her hand, nudges Reaga
Ronnie. It's Ed Meese. Something’s happened. Ronnie, wake up.
! She puts the phone in his hand. He opens his eyes, blee
Hmm?
Sorry, sir, I would have woken you up earlier, but I knew you were tired, and well..Wwe, um, we were just attacked by two Libyan jets. We fired back, though—shot them down. Pause.
Is that it? 142
It happened about 5 hours ago. As I say, I would have woken you up, but..Everything’s been handled.
Okay. Well..thanks for handling it. He hangs up, and goes back to sleep. Nancy’s wide-awake.
Ronnie, what is it?
Nothing. Ed’s taken care of it. He goes back to sleep. Nancy stares at him, alarmed. Afte a moment, he begins to snore. DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE: JOHNNY CARSON ON “THE LATE SHOW”.

There are only two reasons you wake up Ronald Reagan. One is World War III. The other is if “Hellcats of the Navy” is on the late show. AUDIENCE LAUGHTER. INT. DEAVER’S OFFICE - DAY Nancy slams the Washington Post down on Deaver’s desk, furious.
And it’s not just Johnny Carson. Look at what Art Buchwald wrote. And Jack Anderson. Everyone in the entire country is laughing at Ronald Reagan! Deaver winces. From the corner, Jim Baker admits:
It doesn’t make Ed Meese look too good, either.
It’s not just Ed Meese, it’s you. One of you should have woken him up when it happened. Not 5 hours later. 143
(to Deaver) Maybe we should take Ed off foreign policy. It’s not his strength.

Yes, take him off foreign policy. And from now on, whenever anybody asks if the President has been informed of something, no matter what it is, tell them, “The President is aware of it.” “The President is aware of everything.” Got it? Deaver and Baker look at each other, and nod. Nancy starts out. Pause. Turns back to the men.
It’s not easy for him. He has so much to do..to think about. It would be too much for any man... She's about to say something more, but decides not to. Sh turns, and walks out.
Reagan on a chaise, legal tablet on his lap, pencil in hand, staring out the window at the rain. Nancy looks in.
I thought you were taking a nap. He comes to. Speaking slowly, thoughtfully:
I was thinking about that boy.
What boy?
The boy who shot me. He was a nice boy. Just a little mixed-up.
Ronnie, he tried to kill you. 144
He tried to kill me, but God let me live. God spared me, for a reason. And I think I know the reason. } Nancy comes in, and sits down beside him. Lays her head gently on his shoulder. He continues:
God spared me, because he wants me to lead our country out of the cold war with Russia.
(gently) Ronnie..You don’t need to get shot, in order to end the cold war.
I know..but I’ve been praying about it..And God told me—-he wants me to end the cold war. Pause. A shadow of worry crosses Nancy’s face.
| And that’s why he saved your life? }
(nods) And that’s why I’ve got to forgive that | boy. Because he was part of God’s plan. Nancy nods.
Okay. But even if you forgive him..I won’t. I’‘ll never forgive him. Ever. He takes her hand, kisses it tenderly.
‘And that’s your burden, isn’t it, Mommy? You can’t forgive people for being..people.
Not when it comes to you. | REAGAN . : I thank God I have you. You see people so ) much more clearly than I do. If I didn’t
145  have you, I could end up in a lot of trouble, you know that? She laughs. He pulls her close, and kisses her cheeks, he nose, her lips, as:
When I woke up in the hospital, and saw your face..I said to God, Please God don’t ever make me face a day without her.
I love you, Ronnie.
I love you, too, Mommy. More than anything in the whole wide world.
It’s silent, crude. Latin American guerrillas in a jungle unloading crates of ammo and weapons.

head_text.subj: CRATE BEING OPENED, GUNS BEING REMOVED

text: Reagan in a darkened room, watching the movie, as WILLIAM CASEY, (60's) head of the CIA, mumbles next to him:
This is Nicaragua. These are the Contras, they’re fighting to overthrow the Nicaraguan dictator. The dictator is supported by the Reds. All we’ve sent the Contras so far is a bunch of guns.
Reagan nods, grimly.

Except for last week, when somebody in California sent the Contras a helicopter. One lousy helicopter. (pause) It’s the same in Afghanistan. And Cuba. The dictators are supported by Moscow. Moscow sends them everything they need. Deaver, Baker, and Meese are sitting nearby. — - 146
Jesus, I can’t understand a word Bill Casey is saying.
All those CIA guys mumble. I think they learned it from Bill. Al Haig interrupts from a few seats away, irritably:
Why is everybody whispering? REAGAN. Bill Casey’s saying they need more helicopters in Nicaragua.
Christ, it’ll be Vietnam all over again.
What’s wrong with that? Maybe this time we'll win. The movie ends. The projectionist turns off the film, and raises the shades. Outside, it’s raining.
Thanks, Bill. You get those Contras whatever they need.
Wait a minute, sir. He can’t do that. He can’t just—he needs an executive order—
I just gave him an executive order.
But I haven’t even made up a foreign policy statement—

You make up a statement, then. Write it up, so we can give the Contras anything they need. Haig is about to have an apoplectic fit. Reagan doesn’t notice, turns to Bill Casey, who is packin his briefcase, and heading out. 147 ‘aaa?
Oh, and Bill—tell the State Department, good work on the movie. Though it was a little long.
(mumbling) Yes, sir. I will, sir. Casey goes. The troika is about to follow him, when Reaga takes a letter from his desk, and hands it to Al Haig.
Al, one more thing. I want you to take a look at this letter I wrote, over the weekend. I’m going to send it to Brezhnev. Haig emits a thinly-veiled snort of disdain.
So you did write a letter? Haig starts reading it. Reagan explains to the troika:
I told him we should get the ball rolling on arms talks, but I’m still going ahead with the missile defense system. Haig throws the paper down on Reagan's desk.
No, sir. No. No, we're not having any summits—
I’m not saying right away, Al. I’m laying the groundwork—
Sir. I’m the Secretary of State, this is my job! And~and-this will never work.
Why not? Haig is about to explode. 148
Because-—because for one, your letter sounds like it was written by a rank amateur. Deaver, Baker, and Meese glance at each other. Haig sees it:
There you go again, you 3, looking at each other. You’re always looking at each other.
Al, come on-
You’ve been undermining me, ever since I started this job! You won’t even let me be alone with the President!
That’s not true— Haig turns on Reagan, in a fury.

Frankly, Mr. President, I can’t put up with this any longer. Either I’m the Secretary of State or you are. And well, if this pattern continues..I will be forced to submit my resignation. Silence. The troika cock their heads at Reagan: here’s yo chance. Reagan freezes.
Nancy comes down the hall, carrying her calendar. She sto at Helene’s desk, outside Reagan’s office:
Helene, what do you know about the Gridiron Club?
Oh, that’s the Washington press club. Every year they have a roast for the President and the First Lady. It’s a little rough, but they don’t mean anything by it. 149 ‘ute?
Oh, that explains everything.
Why?
Well, some of the staff suggested I should do a little something of my own.
Oh yeah? Really?
Reagan looks intensely uncomfortable, reaches for his jar of jellybeans.
Gee, Al..I don’t want you to resign.
I don’t want to resign either, but...
Have a jelly bean.
Yes, sir.
The purple ones are good. And the black ones. As Haig puts the jelly beans in his mouth, he seems to relax, slightly.
Listen, sir. Why don’t we send your letter, along with another letter that I’ll draft for your signature.
That sounds good. What do you boys think? This to Deaver, Baker, and Meese, who try not to look at each other, this time.
What’s your letter going to say, Al? 150
I don’t know. I’1l have to think about it.
Nancy looks up, as Al Haig comes out of the Oval Office eating jelly beans, and muttering angrily.
Hello, Al. He doesn’t hear Nancy. He storms off, mumbling to himself Nancy opens the door, and enters Reagan’s office.
As Nancy enters, Reagan’s raging to Deaver, Baker, and Meese.
“Rank amateur”! Who does that sonofabitch think he is? I’m the goddam President of the United States, I’m his boss!
Why didn’t you say that to him?
He keeps putting his head on the block, sir. You've got to chop it off.
George Shultz would make a great Secretary of State. Sir. Sir? Reagan is heading for another door.
If it’s alright with you, this administration has to pee. He slams into the bathroom. Baker, Meese, and Deaver noti Nancy standing there.
Has he ever fired anybody face-to-face?
Nope. 151 i!
Only me.
Nancy sitting in front of her mirror, in her nightgown, brushing her hair. Reagan is in bed, exhausted.
Ronnie, Al Haig has got to go.
| Al’s not such a bad guy. He gets a little | worked-up, that’s all.
No, Ronnie. No. You know what he did, while you were in the hospital?
I heard, he thought he was going to take control, but that’s not so bad—
That’s not so bad? Ronnie, he wants to control everything you do. And you're the President of the United States.
I know, but—

He doesn’t like your process. He doesn’t agree with your agenda. He wants total control over foreign policy. Ronnie, he’s not a peacemaker. He’s not. He groans, picks up the remote and switches on the tv. It Johnny Carson. Nancy sits on the bed, blocking his view o the tv.
If you don’t get rid of him, it’s going to look like you’re afraid of him.
I’m not afraid of him—
: But that’s how it looks. To your staff. To everybody in the Cabinet. You can’t afford 152
to be afraid of anyone. They’ve got to know, you’re running the show.
Jesus Christ, Nancy—
Jim Baker thinks you should get George Shultz. He told me so. George Shultz is a peace-maker. Get rid of Al, Ronnie, or you’re never going to end the cold war. He suddenly explodes:

Alright, okay, I get the message. I hear you. Now get off my goddam back, okay? Pause. She gets up from the bed, and heads into the bathroom to brush her teeth. Reagan stares sullenly at Johnny Carson, as he delivers a big, easy golf swing.

A hot day. Outside the fence, THREE HOMELESS GUYS lying o a blanket. Their signs read: “Homeless Because of Ronald Reagan”; “Homeless Vet”; and “Will Work for Food”. INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - CONTINUING
Reagan getting dressed. Nancy hands him a letter. He glances at it, tucks it into his jacket. They exchange a kiss.
Al Haig steps out of the elevator and heads down the corridor toward the Oval Office..passing Deaver, Meese, a Baker..who stop talking, and stare after him until he disappears into Reagan’s office.
Reagan stands, as Al Haig enters.
Hello, Al. 153 ‘eit!

(stiffly) Mr. President, I’m here to deliver 2 letters. The first one concerns the repeated interference that I have endured in my conduct of foreign affairs. The second is a memo concerning my differences with certain Cabinet members, who have made it their business to make my job as Secretary of State impossible. Reagan passes his hand over his brow-he’s sweating.
(uncomfortably) I see. Well, Al..as it happens, I have a letter for you, too.
(surprised) You do?
Reagan hands him Nancy’s letter, and turns away, shufflin through his desk, as if looking for something. Haig reads the letter. It’s short.
(stunned) What...?
I just want you to know, Al..This country will always be grateful to you for your services.
But..but I haven't resigned, yet.
(nodding to the letter) Yes, you have.
No, I haven’t.
If you want, you can go back to your office, and write your own letter. 154
Wait a minute. Can’t we talk about it?
Um.I have a couple phone calls to make... Haig is suddenly on the verge of tears, whispering:
~ But I don’t want to do it, I want to stay.

Sure, Al..but um.would you mind if I asked you to keep working until the Senate can confirm your successor? A SEQUENCE OF IMAGES -— Hospital after hospital being boarded up. Signs saying “Closed” . A LINE OF HOMELESS PEOPLE in front of a soup kitchen. A FAMILY living in their car. A FORMER MENTAL PATIENT sitting in the rain, on the sidewalk, laughing, smiling, talking to the air, catching the rain in her hands, and drinking it.

Rain falls against the windows, as MOVERS are crating in large wooden crates. Nancy’s unpacking one of them, helpe by the Butler and Betsy Bloomingdale. Tearing through the packing, she pulls out an elegant gol colored plate, bordered with Imperial Blue.
Oh my God..it’s beautiful.
They’d better be. The set cost more than $200,000.
What shall I do with the old dishes, Mrs. Reagan?
Straight to Goodwill, darling. 155
(laughs) Don’t listen to her. See if we can donate them to the Smithsonian. Nancy continues pulling out cups, saucers, etc. A woman enters—ANNE ROGERS (34), attractive, ambitious.
Good morning, Mrs. Reagan. May I ask what we're doing? Betsy throws Nancy a curious glance.

Anne, this is Betsy Bloomingdale, an old friend of mine. Betsy, this is Anne Rogers—my new PR person. (wryly) Her job is to make people like me. Anne Rogers doesn’t think this is so funny, turns to Bets
Mrs. Bloomingdale, am I to understand that you and your husband donated this new china?
Yes, you are, darling. It’s our gift to the nation. Anonymous.
You'll be wanting a tax write-off.
Well... Anne turns to Nancy.
I'll need to know the cost of each item—at your convenience, of course. I’1ll be back. She goes. Betsy turns to Nancy:
Where’d you get Miss Bitch?

Secret Service has cordoned off the GLITTERING GUESTS as the Presidential limousines arrive. Neil” Reagan and Nancy emerge—he’s in black tie, she’s stunning and smiling. They head for the club entrance..passing a SMALL GROUP OF HOMELESS ACTIVISTS who are waving signs:
What do we want?
Homes!
When do we want ‘em?
Now! ONE OF THE DEMONSTRATORS tries to rush up to Nancy, but i stopped by a POLICEMAN.
Let ‘em eat cake, Queen Nancy! Let ‘em eat cake! A LEGLESS MAN ON A CART scoots his way to the front of the crowd, trying to push past the Secret Service:
Hey, Nancy! The cost of your dress would feed me for a month! Nancy tries to ignore them. Reagan smiles and waves at them, continues.
Reagan and Nancy are sitting on the dais, flanked by Edit and Loyal Davis, VICE PRESIDENT BUSH AND BARBARA BUSH, AMBASSADORS..Deaver, Baker, Meese, GEORGE SHULTZ, THE NEW

head_text.subj: SECRETARY OF STATE, AND DON REGAN, SECRETARY OF THE

text: TREASURY (we’ll meet them later). The EMCEE stands behind a podium, addressing the audience of journalists, politicians, and glitterati.
The Gridiron Dinner has been an annual event in Washington for more than a ) hundred years. Tonight, the Washington press corps prepares to roast the most 157
powerful person in town..and I’m especially happy, because she brought her husband with her... AUDIENCE LAUGHTER. Nancy smiles uncomfortably. Reagan is laughing.
Keep in mind, if you would, our motto is “We may singe, but we never burn.” MORE AUDIENCE LAUGHTER. Reagan puts his hand on Nancy’s knee, smiling:
Well, Mommy, I do believe this is going to be the most elegant lynching we've been to in a while.

MALE REPORTER DRESSED UP AS NANCY IN A DESIGNER GOWN.He’s pushing a rack of dresses onto the stage, singing (badly) to the tune of “Second Hand Rose”: MALE REPORTER/”NANCY” (singing) Secondhand clothes I give my secondhand clothes To museum collections and traveling shows. They were oh-so-happy that they got ‘em. Won't notice they were ragged at the bottom. Goodbye, you old, worn-out mess, I never wear a frock more than once. Nancy stands up, abruptly, and leaves the dais. Reagan se her go, glances at the audience. Edith leans over to Reagan, whispers:
Where the hell’s she going?
Don’t know. The ladies’ room, probably. Nancy passes behind Deaver, who mutters, smiling:
Go get ‘em, tiger.
As Nancy arrives backstage, Tony and his ASSISTANT grab her, and whisk her away.
Doing a strip-tease, as the audience roars with laughter.

Calvin Klein, Adolfo, Ralph Lauren, and Bill Blass. Ronald Reagan’s mama’s going strictly First Class. Rodeo Drive, I sure miss Rodeo Drive in frumpy Washington. Secondhand rings. Donate those old, used-up things. Designers deduct ‘em. We're living like kings. So what if Ronnie’s cutting back on welfare? , I’‘1l1 still wear a tiara in my coiffed hain... The reporter is down to a tagged corset and torn stocking as... A FIGURE COMES ONSTAGE in a bizarre costume: Donald Duck boots, a white feather boa, strings of pop-it beads, a floppy plumed hat, and a red and yellow Hawaiian skirt he together with safety pins. For a moment, the entire audience hesitates, confused. Th they realize it’s Nancy, and issue a COLLECTIVE GASP. People jump to their feet and start to applaud, as Nancy swings into her lyrics:

(singing) Secondhand clothes I’m wearing secondhand clothes. They’re all the thing in spring fashion shows. IMAGE - A PAIR OF HOMELESS WOMEN OUTSIDE, sitting on the dark sidewalk, wearing a pair of tin foil antennas. Her friend is going thru a shopping cart of Goodwill clothes, trying them on. 159

(singing) Even my new trench coat with fur collar, Ronnie bought for ten cents on the dollar. The china is the only thing that’s new. BACK TO NANCY, strutting her stuff back and forth on the stage, having a laugh-riot:

(singing) Even though they tell me that I’m no longer queen, Did Ronnie has to buy me that new sewing machine? Secondhand clothes, secondhand clothes, I sure hope Ed Meese sews. The laughter is tearing the roof off the place, as Nancy grabs a plate that has been painted to look like her Whit House china, throws it on the floor, and shatters it. As she kicks up her yellow rubber boots and takes a bow.. JOURNALIST IN THE AUDIENCE calls to her from the wings:

Washington loves you, Nancy! Nancy smiles, perfectly aware that it’s only a “Washingto compliment”, then looks to the dais, where Reagan is cheering with the others, watching her proudly. She winks at him.

head_text.subj: DRUMS WITH A REALLY LOUD, TRASHY 4-PIECE BAND BANGS OUT A

text: HOT TANGO as incredibly good-looking GREGORY HARRISON (20's), whirls and struts on stage, in nothing but a stockbroker’s shirt, tie, and a shiny gold G-string. The WOMEN IN THE AUDIENCE are screaming with delight, as Harrison whips off his tie, and flings it into one woman’ lap..followed by his cuff-links, which land in another woman’s lap, and his shirt, which lands in the lap of.. shy, demure Patti, who’s sitting at a stage-side table with her GIRLFRIENDS. As Harrison steps off the stage, heading towards Patti, h girlfriends fall into hysterics. Patti freezes like a dee in the headlights of... HARRISON’S BULGING G-STRING AS IT COMES CLOSER AND CLOSER Harrison arrives at Patti, and yanks her to her feet, and starts dancing with her. Patti freezes with mortification as he vibrates against her. Then she melts, and starting dancing with him. THE CROWD SCREAMS LOUDER. Patti and Harrison are moving as one—it’s so tacky, it’s almost pornographic. INT. RON AND DORIA’S WEST VILLAGE APT. - NIGHT Ron and Doria transfixed, watching Patti and Harrison on their tiny tv.. INT. MAUREEN’S TEXAS APT. - TWILIGHT Maureen watches Patti’s movie as she eats dinner with her new husband DENNIS. She nearly chokes on her taco. INT. MICHAEL’S LIVING ROOM - TWILIGHT Michael, Colleen, and their two young kids watching Patti movie, in their suburban living room. As Harrison starts bend Patti backwards and stick his tongue down her throat..Michael grabs the remote, and changes the channel REAGANS’ COLOR TV - Harrison frenching Patti as the CROWD SCREAMS. 161
Oh. My. God... Reagan and Nancy are sitting in chairs, in front of their tv dinners, staring at the tv--their forks frozen, halfwa to their mouths. As Reagan slowly puts his fork down:
i | Well, you've got to admit..she’s talented...
Talented? You call this talent? This is pornography! And you’re the President of the United States! How can she do this to you?

(laughs) Oh now. She’s just doing it for attention. And who knows? Maybe it’1l help get her a start in show-business... Nancy SCREAMS WITH FURY. Reagan LAUGHS EVEN HARDER. INT. PATTI’S APARTMENT - NIGHT | Patti lying in bed with her boyfriend, PAUL GRILLEY. He yoga instructor. Spacey, but sweet. They’re watching Patti’s move on tv.
So what are your parents going to say, when they see this?
I don’t care. I only see them on tv and in magazines. As far as I know, they don’t even exist, anymore.
(laughs) Well, one of these days I’1l have to meet them.if only to ask their permission.
Oh, Paul..We don’t need their permission to get married. 162
Sure we do. I want them to like me. After all, they're going to be the grandparents of our children. He’s nuzzling her neck and ear. She turns skittish.
Children?
I’m real sentimental, that way. I want a little house with a picket fence, and at least 5 screaming brats. Patti laughs a little. Her face filling with guilt.
Patti and Nancy, in Nancy’s bedroom.
So you want to marry this man..who grew up in a trailer park..and have children by him.
God, Mom. I love him.
But he’s a yoga instructor. What are you two going to live on?
I work, you know. I have my career.
You mean, the movies?
Yes. Nancy tries to sweeten her voice.
Have you told him you can’t have children?
-No. I just..I don’t want to put him through that. I want to... She comes over to Nancy, and kneels beside her: 163

Please, Mom. Please try to understand this-I want to be perfect for him. I want to give him the kids that he wants and...and I want to be the woman he wants..isn’t that pathetic? Nancy strokes Patti's brow resignedly, with a trace of bitterness:
No, my darling. It's not pathetic. We all want to be perfect for our husbands.

L..I talked to a doctor, he said I could probably get my operation reversed..it’s major surgery..it’s very expensive.but I could have children again. (reluctantly) Only I’d have to come clean with Paul..
No, I don't think so. Tell him something else is wrong. There are other reasons women have surgery. Patti stares at her mother, incredulously.
You mean, you want me to go through a major operation, and not tell him why?
If you want your father to pay for it. PATTI. Mom, would you do that? Would you keep such a big secret from the man you were going to marry? Nancy changes the subject.
Patti, you hate everything your father stands for-but now, when you need his money, you come back and ask him to rescue you. 164
I never asked to be rescued. I only asked to be, loved—

And we do love you. (pause) If you want us to pay for your operation, it will be our doctors..ocur way. You will tell no one. Not the press. Not your friends. Not even Paul. Those are our terms. Patti stares at her.
Why do I do this? Why do I come back to you, over and over, when it always turns out the same way?
Should I assume you’re going to wear white to the wedding?
The lights are dark, and the shades are pulled. Reagan, Baker, Deaver, Meese, and George Shultz are watching a State Dept. documentary on Iran. The room is thick with tension.

It’s a grainy, hand-held picture..Khomeini standing on a balcony over a crowd of CHANTING IRANIANS. An American fl burning. A dummy of Reagan being hung, from a street-lamp Bill Casey stands in the picture, narrating, as Iranian rioters flicker across his face:
This is Beirut..There’s Khomeini...
(from the dark) When is that guy going to die? He must be 90 years old. George Shultz leans over, whispers to Deaver: 165
Since when did we start showing movies in the Oval Office?
Not bad, huh? State Department makes ‘em. (nod to Reagan) He doesn’t like to read, and he gets bored listening. Anyway, State love making them, and he loves watching them.
The documentary ends with a projection: the face of a whi American male (WILLIAM BUCKLEY, 50), pale. Scared. He hol the front page of a Lebanese newspaper against his chest.
This is William Buckley, our CIA station chief in Beirut.
Louder.

(mumbling louder) This is William Buckley, our CIA station chief in Beirut. He was kidnapped 3 days ago by Lebanese terrorists who are being supported by Iran. We don’t think they want to kill him. But we are extremely concerned that he will be forced to reveal the names of other CIA agents in the area.
Reagan stares at Buckley’s photograph, stricken. Nearby, George Shultz, Jim Baker, and Mike Deaver.

We've been flooded with calls from Iranians and Iranian exiles. offering to provide us with intelligence..Very fancy intelligence..internal political information..in return for weapons. Reagan has stopped listening.
What about Buckley’s family? Have we talked to them?
They know he’s been kidnapped, sir. 166
I’ll have to call them. They must be out of their minds with worry. Jim Baker leans over to Deaver: Reagan continues to stare at Bill Buckley’s photograph,
Don’t let him call the family. If he talks to them, this whole thing will become about liberating a hostage. the voices around him rise to a level of near-panic:
Maybe we could set up some kind of prisoner exchange—we give them one of their terrorists, in return for Buckley—
No. No prisoner exchange. This administration does not negotiate with terrorists.
But the Iranians want stuff from us. They want weapons, anything, for their war on Iraq—
No. Iran is a terrorist nation. We do not negotiate with terrorist nations.
But if Buckley gives them the names of other CIA agents, we’re all screwed—
You negotiate over Buckley, you know what will happen? We’ll get more kidnappings. More Americans, more CIA agents.
But what about Buckley? What are we going to do-screw him? We’re just going to leave him there? And what the hell are we going to say to his family? 167 as Seas

An explosion of bubbles, as Reagan dives into the water, his lifeguard suit. He swims down...down...searching..HIS THUMPING... Suddenly Bill Buckley’s face looms up in front of him, li a white ghost. Eyes wide open. Drowning. Reagan grabs Buckley under the arms, and starts swimming toward the surface..but Buckley's body is heavy, awkward. INT. REAGANS’ BEDROOM - WHITE HOUSE - NIGHT Reagan is moaning in his sleep. Nancy leans over him:
Ronnie, honey..Ronnie wake up..you’re having a bad dream..Ronnie. She touches him arm. He jumps, opens his eyes. In a panic
Where am I? Where am I? Bill!
You're here, honey..you’re with me..it's okay..It’s okay...
I've got to get him out..But he’s so heavy..I can’t lift him.
Shhh...It’s okay, honey..Lie down..Lie down... She coaxes him into lying down, snuggles close, using the warmth of her body to comfort him:
There, there..Everything’s going to be okay..Everything’s going to be just fine...

MENDELLSOHN’S WEDDING MARCH..Doria in a matron-of-honor dress, coming down the grassy aisle.flanked by DOZENS OF WEALTHY SMILING FACES..Everything is covered in flowers.. behind trees and flowered trellises, the bland, sun-glass faces of Secret Service agents are peering, watching... 168

Patti appears, resplendent, in a gorgeous white bridal gown, orange blossoms in her hair. Trying to smile, trembling on her father’s arm. ‘nse? She passes the Betsy and Arthur Bloomingdale, the Tuttles all her parents’ California friends. They’re all smiling benevolently. So is Mike Deaver. She passes Nancy, who’s in the front row wearing a glamorous suit, smiling broadly. Next to her, Ron is smiling even more broadly.
(whispering to Nancy) Mom..Where’s Michael and Maureen?

(shakes her head, murmurs) They didn’t get their invitations until too late. A frown flickers across Ron’s face. ANGLE - Patti and Reagan arrive at Paul, who is dressed i all white, wearing love beads. He’s a smiling flower-chil of love. Together they all turn and look up at the Reverend Donn Moomaw, who is enormous in his celebrant’s robes, holding Bible, and beaming down at them like God, Himself.

The reception is underway. On one side of the garden, a group of INDIAN MUSICIANS are playing traditional music o sitars, as Paul and Patti (now in yoga clothes) lead THEI FRIENDS through a series of yoga exercises and meditation PATTI’'S FRIENDS Shanti, shanti, shanti..ommmmmm... ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE GARDEN, the string quartet is playing some light Bach. WAITERS cruise with trays of hor d'oevres and champagne. Nancy and Betsy Bloomingdale are heading indoors.
Well, at least she’s not living in sin, anymore. ee;
Nancy and Betsy are in the ladies room, fixing their make up.
Look at you. “Her daughter got married today in a yoga ceremony, but tonight, her hair still looks fantastic.” Nancy laughs.
It’s Tony’s assistant. We brought him out for the wedding. He’s not Tony, but he’s good enough. Betsy smacks her lips in the mirror, as:
Yes, well. Nobody’s Tony. Not even. Tony’s Tony, anymore.
What do you mean?
Oh, Nance. Didn’t you know? He’s dead. (lowers her voice) Died last week..of you-know-what.
(stunned)
Come on, honey. You knew he was gay.
Yes, but..I didn’t..He didn’t tell me..
Everybody on earth knew. I mean, we've all been having a bad hair day for months.
My God. My God..Tony is dead..When is the funeral? Betsy sighs, with a flicker of genuine sadness. 170
You don’t think there’s actually going to be a funeral, do you? (pause) His parents are burying him. Nobody knows where. Come on. You need a nice, big glass of champagne. Betsy drags Nancy out.
The Presidential limo moving slowly down the palm-tree studded boulevard...
Nancy and Reagan sitting in back. She’s staring out the window.
He was sick for months, but I never knew. Nobody ever told me. Reagan pats her hand, consolingly.
Try to remember what the Bible says.
What’s that?
They that live in sin shall die in sin. Nancy looks at him. He reaches over to the bar, unscrews bottle of water, and pours himself a glass.

Ronnie..I want you to do something. Anything. All these young boys, all these children, drug addicts, they’re dying of AIDS, but nobody’s..nobody’s doing anything about it. Nobody even wants to talk about it. Reagan takes a sip of his water, and looks out the window Impenetrable.
Say something. 171
She waits..and waits..no response. She’s dying inside. TIGHT SHOT - A 17-YEAR-OLD GIRL. She has the pimples of. teenager, but she talks like an old woman. Flat, dead:

I didn’t start out a drug addict. My mother was a single mom, she worked in a mental hospital. When the hospital was closed down, we went on unemployment, but unemployment only lasts so long. So when my mom ended up on welfare, and gave me to my aunt and uncle. I didn’t see her for like 6 years. But my cousin was into crack. She gave me some. Sometimes we'd turn tricks-not a lot, just enough to buy stuff. But then I started doing it more and more. I got so I was doing crack in the daytime, and wetting my bed at night. Finally my aunt and uncle found out, and they were going to put me in rehab, so I ran away. Man. Living on the street.. you’d better be doing drugs, or you'll lose your mind. The girl laughs, bitterly. The others laugh, too. PULL BACK TO REVEAL A CIRCLE OF RECOVERING DRUG ADDICTS. Nancy, her assistant KATHY OSBORNE, and the DIRECTOR OF T REHAB PROGRAM. In the b.g., several Secret Service agents
(visibly moved) I don’t understand..Wasn’t there anyone else you could talk to? Your relatives? Your teachers? Your minister? Your doctor? Somebody? The kids laugh. Nancy flushes, embarrassed.
There used to be hospitals. Clinics. After-school programs. That’s all gone, now. Government cut-backs. Nancy is speechless. The director stands up:
Thanks, guys. Let’s take a break and have something to eat. Can we thank Mrs. Reagan for coming today? 172  Everyone claps.

Nancy standing on the balcony overlooking a crowd of cheering, healthy TEENAGERS—not one of these kids has a problem in the world. They’re all wearing “Just Say No” buttons. Tons of media. Tons of Secret Service.
(calling down to the kids) What do we do, when someone offers us drugs? The crowd yells back, as one, along with her:
Just! Say! No! She’s laughing happily, as she fires the next question:
What do we do, when someone asks us to help them sell or carry drugs?
Just! Say! No!
What do we tell our friends to say, if one of them is offered drugs?

(louder than ever) dust! Say! Noooooccce! A flurry of multi-colored balloons saying “Just Say No” i released into the air. Nancy clasps her hands together, s proud, as she watches them fly up into the blue sky. ANGLE - Bill Shelby on the ground, turning to one of his FELLOW-JOURNALISTS, with a cynical grin:
Gee. Why didn’t I ever think of that?
173 Sua?

head_text.subj: NANCY'S FACE AGAINST THE BLUE ARIZONA SKY -

text: Nancy, wearing sunglasses and a solicitous smile:
- Mother? It’s me. It’s so nice to see you, Mother...You’ re looking wonderful...
Nancy settles into a chair next to her mother Edith, who is hunched over in a wheelchair, her eyes fixed on the brightly-colored blanket that covers her lap.
(brightly, trying) Ronnie and I are in Tucson for the re- election campaign, so I thought I’d just drop by. She reaches out, and smoothes Edith’s blanket.
You like your blanket? I picked it out just for you, back in New Hampshire..It’s more than 150 years old. Oh, and look what else I brought. Pictures. Nancy digs into her purse, pulls out photographs:

This one’s of Ronnie and me in the White Mountains. What a godawful place. I was covered with mosquito bites. Covered. (more pictures) Here we are, at Gettysburg..And here’s us the Grand 01’ Opry, that was fun..0h, and here’s Ron and his wife, Doria. You’ve met Doria, she’s not so bad. They’re the only ones campaigning with us, this time. Michael’s got the grandkids, and Maureen’s working. Oh God, Patti’s writing a book, did I tell you? From somewhere deep inside Edith, comes a low groan. Nanc laughs.
You can say that again. Ronnie and I always said to each other, Someday she’s 174
going to write a book. We just hoped it wouldn’t be until after we were dead. Edith’s index finger is slowly twitching its way around t circumference of a blue flower. Nancy falters.
Ronnie would have come with me to see you today..but the campaign is keeping him so busy..and, and... She picks up Edith’s hand, and begins stroking it, confidentially, whispering:

He’s not well, Mother. He’s tired, but it’s more than that. I’m going to talk to his doctor. I think this job is killing him, I really do. All the tension about Nicaragua, and Soviet Union, and this poor man who’s been kidnapped in Lebanon...Every night, when he’s sleeping, I whisper in his ear, “Peace...Peace.” But it’s too much for him. It would be too much for anyone. And some of those men in his Cabinet... Vipers, Mother. Vipers. I just pray to God I can get him out of the White House in one piece. She notices her assistant, Kathy, signaling to her from t lawn, and pointing to her watch. SEVERAL SECRET SERVICE AGENTS get up from the grass. With a great effort, Edith swings her gaze up to Nancy’s face, searching in it for something recognizable:
Who are you? Nancy gasps, but this isn’t the first time this has happened.
I’m Nancy, Mother. Nancy. Your daughter.
(shaking her head) No. I haven’t got any daughter... 175
Yes, you do.Me. Right here, in living color. A shadow falls across the two of them. It’s the ATTENDANT
We’re taking her in for lunch, Mrs. Reagan. Would you like to come? Nancy glances at her assistant, then looks at her mother.
I guess not. I should get back to Tucson. She stands up, and plants a kiss on her mother’s brow.
Goodbye, Mother. I love you.
Mrs. Reagan..is there any chance your husband could send us an autographed picture? The staff would be so thrilled. We show “Bedtime for Bonzo” at least 3 times a year around here...
I’11 speak to the President.
That would be super. Good luck in the election. This is Reagan country, you know.
Yes..thank you..Goodbye, Mother... Nancy watches the nurse wheel her mother away.
DOCUMENTARY MONTAGE: the 1984 campaign: the “Morning in America” ads..Walter Mondale and Geraldine Ferrarro, hand joined and raised in triumph...
DISSOLVE TO Reagan speaking in a CROWDED HALL...
a “My friends, we live in a world that’s lit by lightning...” 176  In back, COPS are wrestling PROTESTORS out as they sing:
(singing) “All we are saying Is give peace a chance...” SHOUTS. PROTESTS. EVERYONE BOOING EACH. OTHER. DISSOLVE TO: Reagan speaking to a crowd of aerospace engineers on the tarmac at NASA...

“American has always been greatest when she dared to be great. I’m convinced we will be leaders, because the American people would rather reach for the stars than reach for excuses why we shouldn’t..” PURE, UNADULTERATED CHEERS. DISSOLVE TO Reagan addressing a crowd of FARMERS in Iowa..The farmers are hardbitten, cynical. One sobs.

“My friends, ours is the land of the free because it is the home of the brave. America’s future will always be great because our people will be free, united, one people under God, with liberty and justice for all...” He certainly is the Great Communicator.
SUPER: “1984” Nancy at the podium:

Ladies and Gentlemen, I want you to meet my husband, the next President of the United States..Ronald Wilson Reagan! She turns to a huge, huge projection screen, which covers the entire back of the stage. A enormous live-image of Reagan appears on it, smiling. Nancy is a speck in front it, waving to him, blowing a kiss..AS THE CROWD GOES WILD
177 Sowa”
Walter Cronkite:
“And we have President Ronald Reagan, carrying 49 states, receiving 525 electoral votes..to Walter Mondale’s 10..President Ronald Reagan has won 59 percent of the popular vote...”
Reagan standing with Nancy, being sworn in, his hand on h mother’s old, taped Bible...

head_text.subj: THRU THE WINDOWS OF THE WHITE HOUSE BALLROOM

text: The windows burn brightly in the dark. Hundreds of dancin couples moving smoothly around the floor..a swirl of colors..candle-light and burnished silver...

location: IN FRONT OF THE WHITE HOUSE

text: Two cardboard boxes on the sidewalk house the same three homeless guys, shivering in the icy cold. The headlights the passing traffic sweep over them...

Deaver standing in the snow, surveying a small cemetery i the woods. All the graves are under a recent blanket of snow. His TRANSLATOR is talking to CHANCELLOR KOHL’S ASSISTANT. Deaver interrupts them:
(shivering) What’s he saying?
(German accent) He says the Chancellor Kohl thinks this is the prettiest of the cemeteries. It will look good on the television.

I agree. Tell him if Kohl likes it, then the President likes it. We can set up a stand right here..the President can make a little speech about World War Two..lay a 178  wreath..It’ll be very touching. Jesus, it’s freezing. Come on, let’s get a drink. They all laugh, and hurry towards the car.

George Shultz, Jim Baker, and Mike Deaver are riding up i the elevator, along with DON REGAN (50), THE NEW SECRETAR OF STATE, and his cohort ROBERT (BUD) MCFARLANE (late 40's), NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER. Regan is cocky:
I’m telling you, Jim-you’re going to wish you never switched jobs with me. Being Secretary of the Treasury is a whole lot harder than being Secretary of State.
Yeah, right, Don. Life in the Oval Office is one big bowl of cherries.
All you’ve got to do is manage the economy. I’m going to be CEO of. the entire White House. Everybody in this building is responsible to me.

Including the President? Regan and McFarlane laugh. The others smile, exchange a glance. The elevator doors bang open. Jim Baker heads right. Everyone else heads left toward the Oval Office. Regan sidles up to Deaver, whispering:

So, Deaver—tell me. You've known Madame Fuhrer a lot longer than I have. How the hell do you manage to put up with her? Mike Deaver looks at him, stunned. Before he can think of an answer, the journalist Bill Shelby appears out of nowhere, catches his sleeve.
Hey, Mike. Read the German papers today? 179 ‘al?
Come on, Shelby, I got no time for this—
Der Spiegel’s saying that the graveyard the President’s gonna visit in Bitburg has 20 SS buried in it. You know, the guys who gave us Auschwitz? Deaver feels sick.
Reagan, George Shultz, Don Regan and Robert McFarlane are sitting in chairs, listening as Deaver explains:
(humiliated) It had snowed, I couldn’t see what was on the tombstones. I screwed up, I take full responsibility. Don Regan interrupts, scornfully:
That’s no excuse. We’re trying to unify Europe, and you've got the President laying flowers on Nazi-graves. And you learned this from the media?
It‘1l break tonight. Six o’clock news.
Okay, damage control. We call the Germans, find a new site for the ceremony—

I’ve already called them. Chancellor Kohl won’t change the site. He says every graveyard in Germany has a few bad apples. We have to put that behind us. (to Reagan) I’m sorry, Mr. President. I blew it. I'll resign as soon as I can write the letter.
What for? I agree with Kohl. The war’s over. More important, I think I’m meant to go. Deaver is silent. Regan turns on the President, dumfounde 180
Why? Every Jewish organization in the country will be at our throats—
Because God wants me to bring peace to Europe. If he didn’t, he’d have left me dead on the street with a bullet in my chest. .
A portrait of FDR looks down on a JEWISH DELEGATION, led ELIE WIESEL, 70, Holocaust survivor and Jewish leader.

I have seen the SS at work, Mr. President. I have seen their victims. They were my friends, my parents. They were children. (pause) I tell you, Mr. President. You should not go to that place. That place is not. your place. Your place is with the victims of the Ss. . Nancy, Don Regan, and Deaver watch from nearby, as the President frowns very seriously:
Well, as you know, Mr. Wiesel, I’ve added a visit to a concentration camp, Bergen- Belsen... The Delegation winces. Nancy listens, helpless.

The Holocaust was the greatest tragedy in human history. I saw some of it, first hand, as an Army photographer during the war, when I filmed one of the camps. I’11 never forget those horrible images— Nancy gasps—what’s he saying? Regan whispers to Deaver.
I thought he stayed in Hollywood during the war.
He did. 181

(overriding) The war made victims of everybody, Mr. Wiesel. Even though they wore Nazi uniforms, the young men buried in that cemetery are victims of Nazism just as surely as the victims in the concentration camps. END ON WIESEL’S INCREDULOUS REACTION:

A GERMAN HONOR GUARD snaps to attention; a drum rolls as Reagan and a U.S. GENERAL step slowly to the monument, together, carrying a wreath, accompanied by two US MARINE As Reagan and the General lay the wreath and stand at attention, a BUGLER plays the German version of “Taps”. A GROUP OF DIGNITARIES watches: CHANCELLOR KOHL, GERMAN POLITICIANS, AMERICAN GENERALS, Don Regan, and Robert McFarlane. Nancy stands with Deaver. As they whisper, the keep their eyes focused on Reagan.
Nancy..I’ve decided to resign. (she glances at him, alarmed) I offered before, and he turned me down. But I’m doing it, anyway.
(whispering) Mike, you can’t..he needs your protection...

He'll be fine. He’s the Teflon man. This will slide off him. But me..I don’t think so. I don’t think I can live with this. (she looks at him, concerned) This job is taking it out of me. My health is shot. I barely know who my wife and daughter are, anymore. I need.a life. She looks at him sadly. The Honor Guard raises its rifles and FIRES a salute, as Reagan snaps a crisp salute, in return.
Deaver hands Reagan his letter of resignation. A sadness hangs over them ‘both. 182

You’1l see me around. I’ve gotten a job as a lobbyist. I can’t believe the number of people who want to be friends with me, now that I’ve worked with you. They both laugh. Silence. Neither of them can say goodbye Suddenly Reagan pulls him in, and gives him a big hug. ANGLE - The look of surprise on Deaver’s face. EXT. WHITE HOUSE - A SUMMER’S DAY Establishing. INT. REAGANS’' SUITE - OUTSIDE THE BEDROOM - CONTINUING DR. HUTTON, the White House physician, comes out of the bedroom to talk to Nancy.
(quietly) He’s getting dressed. I want to talk to you, first..Has the President been having any abdominal pain, that you know of?
No..No, I don’t think so...
I’m going to recommend a series of tests. He has a mass in his lower abdomen, and I want to check it out.
(turning pale) What do you mean, “Check it out”? What is it?
The media is camped out on the sidewalk.

Reagan is in bed, looking pale and a bit groggy, but clearly glad to see Michael, his wife Colleen, AND THEIR SON, CAMERON (5). The room is full of flowers. On the bedside table, several jars of jellybeans..and Patti’s ne book, Home Front. It has a picture of Patti on the cover. 183 \ cen”
The jar of jellybeans is being passed around, as everyone talks and laughs:
I think Patti’s book is more therapy than anything else. You'll see. Three months on the circuit, and it’1l disappear into oblivion.
It’s okay by me. She was always an argumentative kid. Hell, she should have been a politician. Michael and Colleen laugh. Colleen can see how tired Reag is.
It's late, Michael, we should go. Cameron. Pick up your toys. Michael stands up, reluctantly. Cameron starts to gather his toys.
It was good to see you, Dad. We don’t see each other enough, y’ know? Michael leans over, and they embrace.
Nancy talking to Dr. Hutton:
The good news is, we caught it at an early stage. Now all he needs is a little radiation, and he should be fine. Pause.
Doctor..do you think this could explain why Ronnie..I mean, some of his behavior...
What behavior?
His.his forgetfulness..and he’s..he’s tired, all the time... 184
You'd be forgetful and tired, if you were President of the United States.
Yes..but he’s not the same..something’s wrong.
Don’t worry, Mrs. Reagan. If something were wrong, we’d know about it. Say, that “Just Say No” program of yours is getting a lot of play, isn’t it?
Doctor, I’m trying to tell you, Ronnie’s not well...
Of course he’s not well, he’s just had surgery for cancer. Once he gets back on his feet-maybe a little vacation--you’1l see. He’ll be fine. He’s a warhorse.
(trying to believe him) Thank you, Doctor. He gives her arm a squeeze, and heads down the hall. Nanc stands there, trying to collect herself. Kathy Osborne comes up to her with a cup of tea.
Here’s your tea. It’s a little strong, but you can add some more milk to it, and it will be fine. Nancy turns to her, bitterly:

Everybody keeps saying that. It’s fine. Everything’s fine, they tell me. (pause) Well, everything is not fine. It’s not fine. It’s not. Kathy stands there, looking confused. Nancy heads down the corridor to Reagan’s room. As she arrives, Michael, Colleen, and Cameron are emerging. 185
We're leaving now. They're interrupted by Don Regan and Robert McFarlane, standing up from their seats, nearby. They’re holding briefcases.
(ingratiatingly) Mrs. Reagan, I just want to thank you for letting Bud and me come to the hospital today...
(curtly) I'll be back in 15 minutes. Make it short. She walks Michael and his family to the elevator.

Nancy, Michael, Colleen and Cameron are visible in the lobby, talking. She stoops, and gives a hug to Cameron. PANNING UP THE SIDE OF THE HOSPITAL... ARRIVING AT REAGAN'S WINDOW... «which is open a few inches..Reagan.is visible in bed, talking to Don Regan and Bud McFarlane. SLOWLY ENTERING THRU THE WINDOW..their voices become audible:
His name’s Father Jenco. He was a Catholic aid worker in Beirut, they kidnapped him last week. He’s still alive. Or at least he was, as of yesterday. Reagan’s head comes off the pillow.
For God’s sake, another kidnapping? What the hell’s happening? Bill Buckley, what about him? Is he still alive? Regan turns to McFarlane, who clears his throat:
We don’t know, sir. There’s a rumor— 186
What’s your name?
(flustered) McFarlane, sir. Robert McFarlane. I’m:one of your National Security Advisors, sir. You’ve already met me. Several times.
Really? McFarlane and Regan look at each other, uncomfortably.
Apparently Buckley had a lung infection of some kind..But we can’t get any hard information..I mean, Beirut, you know. It’s a country, it’s a state of mind--
(alarmed) He’s dead? Is that what you’re telling me? Bill Buckley is dead?
It’s only a rumor, sir—
Oh Jesus, Jesus..Bill Buckley is dead...
We don’t know if he’s dead. Right now, all we have is rumors. But Bud here has a proposal, we want you to listen to it—
I couldn't save him..He was an American citizen, and I couldn’t save him.
The Iranians need weapons for their war against Iraq—
They want missiles—
If we give them 100 TOW missiles, it could open up communication with the kidnappers— 187
We wouldn't be negotiating—
Talking, that’s all we’d be doing. We’d be talking—
(almost desperate) Will it save Father Jenco? Regan and McFarlane stop.
(carefully) These people..the people we give the missiles to..they might have an influence on the kidnappers.
We're not negotiating. All we’re doing is opening up communications...
We have a Marine, Colonel.Oliver North..he and I can go to Tehran, and set the whole thing up...
You’re going to go to Tehran?
It’s 100 measly antitank missiles.
But we can’t..We can’t sell weapons to Iran, they’re a terrorist nation..and we’re supporting Iraq...
Iran’s not going to win the war with that. All they’11 do is raise a little a little dust. Reagan is so groggy, he’s having difficulty absorbing the information.
Believe me, sir. All we’re doing is opening up communications. 188  Reagan looks from Regan to McFarlane, and back to His voice has the slightest tinge of dread:
Open ‘em up.
189 Regan.
MUSIC: Band Aid’s Christmas recording (“DO THEY KNOW IT’S CHRISTMAS?”) in aid of Ethiopian famine relief..OVER:

the death of CIA station chief Bill Buckley in Beirut..A airliner is hijacked by Iranian terrorists..newspaper pho of the pilot talking to negotiators on the ground..a body the tarmac..The Achille Lauro adrift in the Mediterranean terrorists visible on deck... The world seems to be teari itself apart. MUSIC FADES...
SUPER: “1985” It’s freezing. Reagan is walking slowly around the lake with GENERAL SECRETARY MIKHAEL GORBACHEV. They’re both bundled up. Talks are going badly:
(Russian accent) This missile defense system of yours— weapons in space—who can control it? It opens up an arms race in space—
How do we know you won’t use your weapons against us?
Because we won’t. I’m saying to you, we won't. Why don’t you believe me?
Why don’t you believe me, when I say that all I want is a shield?
(irritably) Please answer me—what is your answer?
(just as irritably) I am answering, Secretary Gorbachev—-with a question for you. The vein in Gorbachev’s forehead is throbbing with fury. 190

I am too heated and emotional not to show you my sincerity. I beg you..Stop this arms race before it gets started. INT. FLEUR D’EAU (CHATEAU) - DAY Nancy and Raisa sit, having tea. Raisa speaks in Russian. Her TRANSLATOR sits beside her:

I read books by your American women. They say American women are downtrodden...They are paid less than American men..and they have no rights in work-place. Nancy glances uneasily at the SMALL ARMY OF ASSISTANTS AN MEDIA scattered around the room. Cameras FLASHING.
That’s not completely true, Mrs. Gorbachev—
(overriding) And Malcolm X. He says American blacks can not get work. They are treated like slaves.
They're not slaves—
(overriding) In Soviet Union, everyone has job. Everyone is treated same— Nancy interrupts with a steely smile:
Please, Mrs. Gorbachev. Would you like some more tea? EXT. FLEUR D’EAU (CHATEAU) - NIGHT The place is ablaze with lights. A fairy castle.
The bathroom door is slightly ajar. From behind it, Nancy voice: 191
“In the Soviet Union, everyone has job. Everyone is treated same.” Oh yeah?
Is that why you have the gulag? So you can make sure everybody’s working? Is that why Andrei Sakharov can’t get his wife any medical treatment?

head_text.subj: COMING AROUND THE CORNER OF THE DOOR -

text: Nancy is visible in the tub, blowing off steam:

«God help me if I come down with a cold when I’m in Moscow, I’1l1 be damned before I‘1l see any of your so-called doctors! And no wonder your husband always looks so bored—because he’s married to you, you Stalinist— She’s interrupted by a WOMAN’S VOICE, outside the door:
(French accent, timidly) Madame Reagan? I’m just turning down the bed. Is there anything you need?

No. No, thank you. That will be all. Nancy shrinks down into the water, mortified. INT. LIBRARY - FLEUR D’EAU -— CONTINUING In front of a blazing fire, Reagan and Gorbachev are sharing cigars, and brandy. They’re laughing and talking:
(Russian accent) So tell me, is Olivia de Havilland as beautiful as she looks in the movies?

More. Much more. We were on a committee together for the Screen Actors Guild. One night we were all standing around after a meeting, and I said, “You know, Olivia, I 192  always thought you might be a Communist.” She said, “Me? I thought you were one of them!” Gorbachev laughs and laughs.

Okay, I’ve got a joke for you. This is a story of a commissar who visited a collective farm. He stopped the first farmer he met, and asked about life on the farm. And the man said, “It’s wonderful. I’ve never heard anyone complain about anything since I’ve been here.” And the commissar said, “Well, what about the crops?” “Oh,” said the farmer, “the crops are wonderful.” “What about the potatoes?” “Oh, sir,” he said, “the potatoes, there are so many that if we put them in one pile they would touch the foot of God.” And the commissar said, “Just a minute. In the Soviet Union, there is no God.” And the farmer said, “Well, there are no potatoes, either.” They both break up, laughing. NEWSPAPER PHOTO: Reagan, Gorbachev, Raisa, and Nancy standing together at the end of the summit. Everyone’s smiling. Headline: “USA and USSR pledge to seek 50% Reduction in Nuclear Arms”.
